dialogues.speaker: THE VICE-REGAL PALACE
dialogues.text: The imposing capitol building of the British Raj in India We establish then cut into

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNMENT COUNCIL ROOM
dialogues.text: Featuring the Viceroy, Lord Chelmsford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must understand, gentlemen, that  His Majesty's Government -- and the  British people -- repudiate both the  massacre and the philosophy that  prompted it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chelmsford is pacing along one side of a large conference table. Just in front of this is the "British" side -- two generals (a full general and a brigadier), a naval office two senior civil servants, a senior police officer. Acros from them is the "Indian" side: Gandhi, Nehru, Patel, Jin Azad. This time Gandhi is in the middle and speaks with t full authority of a leader. The Indian side acknowledges Chelmsford's disclaimer --  coolly, but accepting it. That lifts Chelmsford's hopes a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I would like to do is to come  to some compromise over the new civil  legis --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you will excuse me, Your  Excellency, it is our view that  matters have gone beyond  "legislation."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is spoken with the cold determination of a man still a It stops Chelmsford in mid-pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think it is time you recognized  that you are masters in someone else's  home. (It chills, stiffens;  Gandhi proceeds only  an iota softer) Despite the best intentions of the  best of you, you must, in the nature  of things, humiliate us to control  us. General Dyer is but an extreme  example of the principle. It is time  you left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The British are stunned almost to speechlessness -- the  audacity, the impossibility of it -- and from Gandhi of a people. The senior civil servant, Kinnoch, is the first t recover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With respect, Mr. Gandhi, without  British administration, this country  would be reduced to chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patient, ironic) Mr. Kinnoch, I beg you to accept  that there is no people on earth who  would not prefer their own bad  government to the "good" government  of an alien power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly, choked) My dear sir -- India is British!  We're hardly an alien power!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi and the others just look at him. Chelmsford is realist enough to recognize that a faux pas has been made, and he strives to get the meeting back on course he intends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if His Majesty could waive all  other considerations, he has a duty  to the millions of his Muslim subjects  who are a minority in this realm.  And experience has taught that his  troops and his administration are  essential in order to keep the peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has deliberately if delicately caught the eye of both  Jinnah and Maulana Azad during this. Gandhi knows the tro this can cause and he answers more for those on his side  than the Viceroy's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All nations contain religious  minorities. Like other countries,  ours will have its problems. (Flat, irrevocable) But they will be ours -- not yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its finality is such that for a moment there is no respon at all, but then the General smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do you propose to make them  yours? You don't think we're just  going to walk out of India.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His smile flitters cynically on the mouths of the others his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... in the end you will walk out.  Because one hundred thousand  Englishmen simply cannot control  three hundred fifty million Indians  if the Indians refuse to co-operate.  And that is what we intend to achieve --  peaceful, non-violent, non-co- operation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at them all, then up at Lord Chelmsford behind t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until you yourself see the wisdom of  leaving... your Excellency.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Close shot -- a crystal decanter. The top is lifted, whis pours. The camera pulls back. We are still in the Council Room, time has passed. The Indian delegation has gone, and the  British are relaxing as a servant pours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mocking his exchange  with Gandhi) "You don't just expect us to walk  out?" "Yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extraordinary little man! "Nonviolent,  non-co-operation" -- for a moment I  almost thought they were actually  going to do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some smiles, but not all of them are quite so  amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Yes -- but it would be wise to be  very cautious for a time. The Anti- Terrorist Act will remain on the  statutes, but on no account is Gandhi  to be arrested. Whatever mischief he  causes, I have no intention of making  a martyr of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is an instruction they all find correct.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: A roar of approval from a huge crowd. We are featuring tw British soldiers, their faces partially lit by a flickeri torch light that reveals their tense wariness. Another angle. And we can see its cause. A huge crowd is  gathered around a platform -- torches sprinkled through i and their mood is confident, belligerent. As their defian roar carries through the night air we see that Gandhi sit cross-legged on the platform. Nehru is with him. Patel, n for the first time in an Indian tunic, and Azad, also in Indian tunic. Desai, Gandhi's new male secretary, is with them. But it is Ba who is speaking at the microphone, who has brought the shout of defiance from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simple, direct) ...but now something worse is  happening. When Gandhiji and I were  growing up, women wove their own  cloth. But now there are millions  who have no work because those who  can buy all they need from England.  I say with Gandhiji, there is no  beauty in the finest cloth if it  makes hunger and unhappiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the end of her speech and she makes the pranam and  turns away. There is applause and noise, but Ba does not  acknowledge it; she simply sits cross-legged behind Gandh who is talking with Patel and Nehru. At last he rises, an the noise and applause increase to something like chaos. In close shot we see other British soldiers watching on t perimeter of the crowd and they are now made even more wa by the enthusiasm of this greeting. Gandhi fiddles with h glasses, preoccupied; finally he looks out over the crowd and holds up a hand -- almost lazily -- and gradually, bu quite definitely, the crowd stills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My message tonight is the message I  have given to your brothers  everywhere. To gain independence we  must prove worthy of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We intercut with the crowd, listening raptly. Gandhi hold up one finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be Hindu-Muslim unity --  always. (A second finger.) Secondly, no Indian must be treated  as the English treat us so we must  remove untouchability from our lives,  and from our hearts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither of these goals is easy, and the audience reaction shows it. Now Gandhi raises a third finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third -- we must defy the British.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the crowd breaks into stamping and applause. Gandhi l it run for a time, then stills it with the one small gest as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with violence that will inflame  their will, but with firmness that  will open their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has sobered the audience somewhat. Now he looks out  across them as though seeking something. Then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English factories make the cloth --  that makes our poverty. (A reaction.) All those who wish to make the English  see, bring me the cloth from  Manchester and Leeds that you wear  tonight, and we will light a fire  that will be seen in Delhi -- and  London!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an excited stir; he silences it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if, like me, you are left with  only one piece of homespun -- wear  it with dignity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close shot -- the ground. As suitcoats, shirts, vests,  trousers, are flung into a pile. Featuring the two British soldiers -- later -- on the edg of the crowd, staring off, their faces now brightly lit b darting flames. Their point of view. A huge triangular pile burns before platform, an excited half-naked crowd swirling in the sha around it. Resume the two British soldiers. They look at  each other with a kind of fear a rampant crowd can excite those who must hold it...

dialogues.speaker: ASHRAM STATION
dialogues.text: The small train station near the ashram. Kallenbach stand by a new (early 1920s) Ford touring car, watching as a tr pulls into the station. As people start to jump off the train he moves forward. Featuring Patel, getting out of a compartment marked "Sec Class." He lugs a bedroll and a bag. Despite the Indian t he now wears he cannot help but look and act like the  incisive, patrician lawyer he is under the skin. As he mo through the crowded platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- just let me get out of  your way, please. (Someone reaches for  his bedroll and bag.) No, thank you, I'll manage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up; it is Kallenbach who is the insistent "helpe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joyous -- it's been  a long time) Ah, Herman! (Of the bags) No, no -- don't destroy my good  intentions. I'm feeling guilty about  traveling Second Class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kallenbach is smiling too. He reaches for the bags again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do it as a friend -- and admirer --  not a servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, in that case!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And grandly, he relinquishes the bags and looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maulana is made of sterner stuff.  Our trains met in Bombay, but he's  back there in that lot somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their point of view. In the chaos of the Third Class we s Maulana Azad coming out of a section of the coach. He is  carrying a baby wrapped in rags. The child's mother with little ones hanging on her has followed him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is -- out Gandhi-ing Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Azad hands the woman the baby and she obviously thanks hi He makes a little salaam to her and moves through the  confusion of the platform toward the camera. Resume Patel and Kallenbach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head at  it all) When I think what our "beloved  Mahatma" asks, I don't know how he  ever got such a hold over us. Is he  back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Now that things are moving he's  going to write and only take part  when it's necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Azad approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Patel) It was a Hindu child and it tried to  wet on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Kallenbach clasp with their free hands, both grinn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. A Muslim beef eater --  I'm only surprised he missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a she.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, that explains it. (He grins.) Well, do I carry your luggage as  penance or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another passenger -- a Miss  Slade. (He turns  automatically, as  Patel and Azad do,  toward the First  Class section.) She's the daughter of an English  admiral. (Patel and Azad look  back at him in quick  surprise. Kallenbach  smiles.) She's been corresponding with him  for a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the camera pans with their glances at they look back  with real interest toward the First Class coach. Porters are unloading the baggage of two or three passeng here and helping some others (English and Indian) to boar In the foreground we see a tall Indian woman in a red sar Farther along there is a large stack of luggage being add to by a porter. An English woman is hovering about it. Sh is well dressed, but rather dreary and unprepossessing, a the camera zooms in toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what does the daughter of an  English admiral propose to do in an  ashram -- sink us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly -- his manner) From the looks of the luggage, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patel grins. Like most witty men, he loves wit in others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to make her home with us --  and Gandhiji has agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patel groans. They turn back to the train and just as the do, the tall Indian woman in the red sari tips a porter,  taking one small bag from him and turns: Mirabehn (Madele Slade) is tall, quite pretty and extremely English despit the sari. The minute she turns, she stops on seeing the n startled Kallenbach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be Mr. Kallenbach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kallenbach recovers sufficiently to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And you would be Miss Slade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) I prefer the name Gandhiji has given  me -- Mirabehn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word means "daughter." Patel and Azad stare at each o in something like bafflement.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROAD TO THE ASHRAM
dialogues.text: An ox labors along in harness. We follow him for a moment then move along the traces of the harness to the Ford tou car that it is pulling. In the car Kallenbach and Mirabeh sit in the front seat, Patel and Azad in the back. Closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of the car) It was a gift and it only worked a  few weeks, but when Gandhi came home  he struck on this idea. He calls it  his ox-Ford. Comfortable -- and yet  more our pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does what little steering is necessary and Mirabehn sm at it all, finding everything delightful. She peers ahead the direction of the distant ashram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might Mr. Nehru be there too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glibly) The irresponsible young Nehru is in  prison -- again. Though there is a  rumor that under pressure from your  country, they will let him out --  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn has turned to look at him. She has the same  sophomoric eagerness and intensity as the young Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't know how closely we follow  your struggle -- (to Patel personally) how many in England admired what you  did in Bardoli. It must have taken  enormous courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in this country one must decide  if one is more afraid of the  government or Gandhi. (Of Azad, Kallenbach  and himself) For us, it's Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn is enthralled by the wit, the modesty that under the words. She faces Kallenbach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a note of wonder) And you're German...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you feel Indian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks she does, and that he would want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It surprises, but it doesn't deflate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've been with him so long --  why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kallenbach, whose size and stillness carry the aura of so great piece of primitive sculpture -- solid, true,  disturbingly profound -- searches inside himself for the  answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'd come to believe I would never  meet a truly honest man. And then I  met one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so profoundly simple and deeply felt that it obviou touches the deeply emotional Mirabehn.

dialogues.speaker: GANDHI'S BUNGALOW
dialogues.text: Ba has a spinning wheel on the small porch and Gandhi is  sitting next to her with another. He is trying to imitate her action -- which is fast and dexterous -- and he gets a terrible jumble. Ba watches, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop -- stop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans across and tries to extricate his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God gave you ten thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (morosely) Eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Ba laughs again and Gandhi smiles, tapping her with  playful reproval on the top of her bent head. There are  footsteps and Gandhi looks up. Patel stands in the doorwa Gandhi's face changes to something like elation. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sardar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means "leader" and it is the name the peasants have gi Patel. Gandhi uses it with an intonation of novelty and  respect. He stands and crosses to Patel, clutching him  emotionally, and it brings a bit of emotion from the  sophisticated Patel. Gandhi holds him back to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you've done is a miracle. You  have made all India proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patel gets hold of himself, and affects his usual glib  cynicism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must have been the only Non-violent  campaign ever led by a man who wanted  to kill everybody every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Not true! (He means himself.) The secret is mastering the urge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles again, then, his arm still around Patel's shoul he turns to greet the others. Azad looks at him, then  facetiously, as though to put down Patel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came Second Class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi laughs again, squeezing Patel's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we can't expect miracles all  the time. (Then to Azad, more  soberly) Your news I understand is not so  good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Azad shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi reaches forward and touches his hand, and he sees  Mirabehn on the porch. For a moment their eyes meet and t Mirabehn moves forward quickly and takes his hand, kissin it, tears running down her cheek. Gandhi touches the top her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, come -- you will be my  daughter...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The camera is on a row of sandals by the door -- Patel's, Azad's, Desai's, Gandhi's. It pans to the room. Gandhi si facing Patel and Azad, Desai in the background, making no of the discussion. Gandhi is carding fiber to thread as t talk. Mirabehn, seated like the others, is almost in the  circle, sitting near Ba, and listening like her. Ba's spi never stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but then some rioting broke out  between Hindus and Muslims -- violent,  terrible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi looks up at Azad, Azad shakes his head solemnly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether it was provoked... (he shrugs, a hint of  suspicion) But it gave them an excuse to impose  martial law throughout Bengal. (He looks at Gandhi,  shaking his head  grimly.) Some of the things the military have  done...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he does not go on. It has a terrible sobriety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the campaign weakening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Azad shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marches and protests are bigger  if anything but with the censorship  here (a nod toward Mirabehn) they know more in England than we  do, and it saps the courage to think  you may be suffering alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi reaches out and touches his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are not alone. And martial law  only shows how desperate the British  are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds Azad's eyes, giving strength. Then he turns to  Mirabehn, made more aware of her by Azad's reference. For moment he looks at her sari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that homespun? Or cotton from  Leeds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tone suggests he thinks it is homespun. Mirabehn nods little choked that his attention is turned to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I sent for it, from here. I  dyed it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi smiles approvingly. Then a shadow --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do the workers in England make  of what we're doing? It must have  produced hardship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has. But you'd be surprised. They  understand -- they really do. It's  not the workers you have to worry  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. (A glance toward Ba.) Ba will have to teach you to spin  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would rather march.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First spin. Let the others march for  a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn nods and looks resignedly at Ba. Ba is spinning. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First lesson: To march, wear shoes,  to spin, do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn looks down at the shoes on her feet -- and then the others and their bare feet -- and she looks up in  grinning, self-conscious embarrassment. Ba smiles at her  affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll teach you all our foolishness,  and you must teach me yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn looks at her, accepting the warmth behind the  teasing. It is the beginning of an enduring friendship.

dialogues.speaker: CHAURI CHAURA
dialogues.text: A small town. Featuring the faces of six Indian police  constables as a torch light parade passes them. There are enough of them in their group to be watching the marchers with a challenging disdain. The marchers are men in loin- clothes and tunics; they brandish torn and ripped English cloth and shout in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home Rule! Long live Gandhi! Buy  Indian! Long live Gandhi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have cut to the parade -- and it is the tail end, goin around a corner ahead. Some of the marchers wave their cl tauntingly at the police. One policeman suddenly steps ou and grabs at a piece of cloth waved at him. He pulls it  viciously from the marcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stuff your damn mouth with it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chases the marcher and boots him with his foot. Anothe marcher runs at the policeman, swinging at him with his p of cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him alone -- he wasn't harming  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another angle -- sudden. He is whacked across the face wi a billy club and falls, clutching his face and spouting b from his nose. Another angle. The police are now all attacking, swinging clubs and kicking at the tail-enders of the march. And th tail-enders begin to scream

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help! Help us! as they try to scramble  away from the attack. Out of shot we  can still hear the disappearing chant:  "Home Rule! Long live Gandhi!"

dialogues.speaker: CONNECTING STREET
dialogues.text: The parade is on this street. A tail-ender, blood streami down his face, runs around the corner. lose shot -- the t ender. As he stops

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Help! Help us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another angle. Some of the marchers turn at the shout.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME THE POLICE
dialogues.text: A few of the tail-enders watching, some running clear of police, some being beaten. Two police have a man on the ground. One policeman looks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their point of view. The corner where the parade has  disappeared. It is now packed with more marchers, more  flooding in from behind. We see the whole street, the marchers massed near the cor spread out, staring at the police, who are now frozen in  their mayhem, staring off at the marchers. For a second, utter silence. And then the police begin to back away from their victims The marchers start to move forward. The police draw their guns, and the marchers suddenly run at them, a guttural r as though they were one single wild beast. Featuring the police. They start to run, some turning to  fire at the pursuing crowd, then running on.

dialogues.speaker: THE POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: A small building for this small town. A policeman on duty holds the door and the fleeing police, first one, then tw more, then the last three, run into the building. The crowd surges around it, smashing windows, hurling sto Close shot. English cloth shirts pushed together and igni Second close shot. Trousers, already aflame, being hurled through a broken window. All around, the noise of the ang surging crowd, stones raining on the building. Shouts: "O Out!" Later. A corner of the building engulfed in flames. The c pulls back and we see the whole building swept with fire. The heat of it keeps the crowd back but they are still  shouting "Out -- Out! -- Out" -- and a sudden cheer. At the door of the flaming building. One policeman appear his face blackened with soot, his hands up over his head. Another appears in the smoke behind him, and they start t come out -- not only the original six but the five or six others who were in the building -- rushing suddenly from heat of the fire. Close shot -- the crowd. We are close on the body of the  first policeman as he runs into the crowd and on the inst we see a sword slash at his arm. Another angle. The crowd massed around the fallen figure, flash of the sword going up over the heads -- a breathles pause -- and it comes down again... savagely. Later. The flames of the crumbled building. The crowd has gone and we only hear the roar of the flames. The camera  pans across the flames, and we see a skull, charred flesh still clinging to it, the eyes black holes, the teeth bar as it burns in the fire.

dialogues.speaker: JINNAH'S DRAWING ROOM
dialogues.text: Close shot -- Gandhi. His face drawn, stunned, as he star emptily at the floor. He is sitting on the carpet in the  center of the room. A moment of silence and then we begin hear the tick of a clock, the sounds of others moving in room, and finally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one bit of news they haven't  censored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another angle. Patel leans with one arm on a table, his m as devastated as Gandhi's; he is looking at an Indian pap on the table by his hand. A moment then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's all over the world... (ironically) India's "non-violence."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has been standing, looking out of a window. He turns, tosses a newspaper on a desk. It is a New York Times and just glimpse the picture of the severed head lying in the smoldering ashes. And now we see Nehru and Azad in the background too. And  Desai. Jinnah as usual in a finely cut European suit, the others are dressed in tunics of homespun as they will be the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bleakly) What can we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sepulchrally) We must end the campaign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to him -- a sense of surprise, but they don't r believe he means the statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After what they did at the massacre --  it's only an eye for an eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he hasn't moved; the  same tone) An eye for an eye only ends up making  the whole world blind. (Now he looks up at  them.) We must stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a baffled smile) Gandhiji -- do you know the sacrifices  people have made?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at him. Gandhi doesn't move. Patel looks up  hopelessly at Jinnah. Azad keeps his eyes fixed on Gandhi sensing, fearing what is going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would never get the same commitment  again -- ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Gandhi with a mounting sense of annoyance. Gandhi is listening, but still withdrawn into himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we obtain our freedom by murder  and bloodshed I want no part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading) It was one incident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Tell that to the families of the  policemen who died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jinnah turns away in anger. Patel sighs. Nehru feels help but he continues to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu -- the whole nation is marching.  They wouldn't stop, even if we asked  them to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi stares into nothing -- mulling that. Finally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will ask. And I will fast as penance  for my part in arousing such emotions --  and I will not stop until they stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru stares at him -- surprised. Azad is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) God! You can be sure the British  won't censor that! They'll put it on  every street corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi does not react. And Nehru ignores the thought too, because like Azad his mind is already on the real danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But -- but Gandhiji people are  aroused... they won't stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi looks up at him -- a resigned fatalism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I die, perhaps they will...

dialogues.speaker: THE ASHRAM
dialogues.text: Mirabehn walks across the grounds toward Gandhi's bungalo She carries a small tray with a pitcher and a glass. We s a few people working in the background, and a mass of peo camped near the entrance, some sprawled, some sitting, so standing -- all waiting. The steps of Gandhi's bungalow. A doctor in a white tunic sits on the porch, reading. On a small table beside him w stethoscope and the equipment to measure blood pressure. looks up at Mirabehn as she mounts the steps, and nods.  Mirabehn reaches the doorway and is suddenly brought up.

dialogues.speaker: TWILIGHT
dialogues.text: In the shadows, Ba sits by Gandhi's mat bed. She is holdi him as he heaves in a spasm of dry retching, his face to wall. When he is finished, he lies almost limp in her arm and she gently lowers him to the mat. She strokes his hea Mirabehn stiffens herself. She is not yet devotee and nur She removes her sandals and walks across the room. Ba looks up at her. She glances at the jug and glass, the nods. She turns to Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I must get ready for evening prayers.  Mirabehn is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She strokes his sweating head again, touches his shoulder and gets up. For a moment the two women hold each other's gaze, then Ba smiles weakly, and leans her head into the  taller Mirabehn's shoulder. With her free hand Mirabehn  touches Ba's head. Then Ba straightens, and leaves withou looking back. Mirabehn bends and sits by Gandhi's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've brought your drinking water.  May I turn you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi struggles to turn, and Mirabehn helps him. When he turns we see that his face is wet with sweat from the dry heaving and his hands and arms are quivering and he canno stop them. She looks at him nervously, then pours a glass from the pitcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a little lemon juice in it.  That is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back, and propping up his head, helps him to si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herman has gone to meet Pandit Nehru --  there was a telegram. Almost  everywhere it has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi swallows with difficulty. He pauses, letting his h fall back and she lowers it down to the mat again. He tri to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it is everywhere, then my prayers  will be answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn looks daunted by his intractability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you find me stubborn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her own honesty) I don't know... I know you are right.  I don't know that this is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi signals her down to him. She bends so she is looki at the floor and he is speaking almost into her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarse, strained) When I despair, I remember that all  through history the way of truth and  love has always won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We intercut their faces, very close, as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There have been tyrants and murderers,  and for a time they can seem  invincible. But in the end they always  fall. Think of it -- always... When  you are in doubt that that is God's  way, the way the world is meant to  be... think of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the very last of it Mirabehn has turned her face t him, touched with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the paternal smile) And then -- try to do it His way. (A tear runs down  Mirabehn's face. She  touches his shoulder.  Gandhi just leans  his head back in  exhaustion.) And now -- could I have another feast  of lemon juice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn straightens up, smiling, wiping the tear from he cheek with mock discipline. She starts to pour water from the pitcher into the glass again, then she turns suddenly her attention caught. Her point of view. The doorway. Nehru stands in it. Kalle and Desai are a step or two behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panditji -- come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands, moving back from Gandhi. Nehru crosses and kneels in Mirabehn's place. Gandhi look up at him and his eyes light. He moves his shaking hand o and Nehru clasps it. A moment of personal feeling between them, then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jinnah, Patel, all of Congress has  called for the end of non-co- operation. There's not been one  demonstration. All over India people  are praying that you will end the  fast. They're walking in the streets,  offering garlands to the police --  and to British soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a victory. Gandhi's face cracks into a tearful grin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (croaked) Perhaps -- perhaps I have overdone  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Nehru chokes with emotion and laughter at the same ti He buries his head on Gandhi's hand, clutching it to him.

dialogues.speaker: THE ASHRAM
dialogues.text: Bright sunshine. A little boy is pulling a goat by a teth He turns with a bright smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Bapu!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverse angle. Gandhi is walking, holding Ba's shoulder f support with one hand, and Mirabehn's with the other. It some days later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. (Of the goat) Don't let her go. If she bumps me I  am done for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy grins at Gandhi's feigned alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I milk her every day,  she's not --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of a motor disturbs them. Gandhi turns. His point of view. Coming into the entrance, along the bu path are two police cars (early 1920s Morris). They have stop because they are impeded by Gandhi's ox-Ford. Four Indian policeman hop quickly out of the second car. British police superintendent, and his British deputy get more decorously out of the first. Another angle. Gandhi has turned with his two props, Ba a Mirabehn. The police are approaching him. Kallenbach is  running from the fields. Nehru is hurrying from another  building carrying sheaves of page proofs. Other ashramite converge from the fields and buildings. The British police superintendent (who is Scottish) stops before Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) Sedition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it is too absurd) You can't be serious! This man has  just stopped a revolution!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably; he  knows) That's as may be. I only know what I  am charged to perform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru stares at him and the policemen with growing  incredulity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it -- even the British  can't be that stupid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panditji -- please, help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stops Nehru. He looks at Gandhi and sighs in unmastere frustration, but he moves to Gandhi's side. Gandhi turns Mirabehn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must help Herman -- and Ba. (He releases her, and  says more loudly to  the others) I have been on many trips -- it is  just another trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at them, then slips his free hand on Nehru's  shoulder and he turns to the superintendent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am at your command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring Gandhi, Ba and Nehru, as they walk to the car b the somewhat surprised superintendent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nehru) If there is one protest -- one riot --  a disgrace of any kind, I will fast  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Nehru firmly. Nehru knows him well enough now not to argue -- even at this, though his face shows the  struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (and now he smiles --  Gandhi to Nehru,  special) I know India is not ready for my  kind of independence. If I am sent  to jail, perhaps that is the best  protest our country can make at this  time. And if it helps India, I have  never refused to take His Majesty's  hospitality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs and Nehru struggles to join in the joke.

dialogues.speaker: THE CIRCUIT COURT
dialogues.text: A quiet hum in a packed courtroom. Armed sepoys line the  wall. Featuring Judge Broomfield and the clerk. The Judge is  flipping through documents on the case, a troubled frown his face. At last, he shuts the folder and nods to the cl The clerk turns and says in a moderately loud voice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the prisoner to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sergeant-at-arms turns and moves to the door at the s of the bench. The courtroom immediately falls silent. The sergeant-at-arms opens the door -- a moment -- and Gandhi enters slowly. He has recovered a bit more, but he still  moves slowly. Featuring Judge Broomfield. As Gandhi enters, he lowers h glasses, places them on his desk, and rises, facing Gandh Featuring two English court reporters. One nudges the oth in astonishment, signaling off toward the judge. Their point of view. The clerk, confused as well as  astonished, see the judge standing, facing Gandhi in resp and dutifully, he too stands. Resume the reporters. A disbelieving exchange of glances, the sound of others standing around them. They glance bac Full shot -- the courtroom. The whole court rises, the  astounded reporters the last of all. Featuring Gandhi. He takes the prisoner's stand. He looks around, a little surprised, a little affected by the  demonstration. He looks up at the judge. For a minute the eyes meet, the judge makes a little bow to Gandhi. Gandhi reciprocates... and the judge sits down. Featuring the reporters shrugging incredulously to each o as they sit once more. Later. The Advocate General is speaking from a folded jou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..."Non-co-operation has one aim:  the overthrow of the Government.  Sedition must become our creed. We  must give no quarter, nor can we  expect any." (He looks up at Gandhi.) Signed M. K. Gandhi, in your journal  Young India, dated twenty-second  March of this year. Do you deny  writing it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. (To the judge) And I will save the Court's time,  M'Lord, by stating under oath that  to this day I believe non-co-operation  with evil is a duty. And that British  rule of India is evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a little shock of reaction around the courtroom. The Advocate General smiles with a brittle disdain, then turns to the judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prosecution rests, M'Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge nods. He turns, glancing at the empty table for defense counsel, and then to Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it you will conduct your own  defense, Mr. Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no defense, My Lord. I am  guilty as charged. (Then testingly) And if you truly believe in the system  of law you administer in my country,  you must inflict on me the severest  penalty possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is almost a cruel challenge to the obviously humane  Broomfield. The reporters scribble, watching the Judge even as they w because the mere doubt in the Judge's face reflects on th whole position of the British to India. Featuring Judge Broomfield. He lowers his glasses soberly staring at them for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is impossible for me to ignore  that you are in a different category  from any person I have ever tried,  or am likely to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at Gandhi and his own respect for him is almo poignantly manifest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a long beat) It is nevertheless my duty to sentence  you -- to six years' imprisonment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunned intake of breath from the whole courtroom, then absolute silence the clerk scribbles the sentence in his  notebook. A pause. The Judge lowers his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a personal statement,  not a real hope) If however His Majesty's Government  could -- at some later date -- see  fit to reduce that term, no one would  be better pleased than I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He folds, and refolds his glasses and then without lookin at anyone he rises. The court rises and he walks stiffly his chambers. Featuring Gandhi. He stands, staring at Broomfield, and n it is his face that shows the respect.

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN ROAD
dialogues.text: Long shot. From far above the hills we see a car travelin along the road. Its style tells us some years have passed Featuring Walker -- close. The reporter from the New York Times, whom we first saw as a younger man in South Africa He is in an open car, turning back to look at something, face intrigued by what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (English accent) Yes, I'm sure that's exactly what  they hoped. Put him in prison a few  years and with luck he'd be forgotten.  And maybe they'd even subdue him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see from Walker's point of view an Indian woman walkin along the road, leading a tall camel that carries sacks o produce. Two young girls in ragged saris walk with her, a a boy of eight leads a smaller camel behind them. They ar staring off at the car. Resume Walker. He swings back around, fascinated with wha he is seeing of India. The car is an early 1930s Morris M

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he certainly wasn't forgotten!  And as soon as he got out he was  back tramping the country, preaching  non-violence and demanding a free  India. Everybody knows another  showdown's coming -- but when, and  over what --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs, "Nobody knows"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I read you account of that  crowd in Calcutta and that he was  twisting the Lion's tail again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collins has suddenly slowed the car, then swerves around pair of elephants hauling logs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (falteringly) ...and I knew something had to give.  And I was determined to be here when  it did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does a reporter in Central America  learn that Gandhi was born in  Porbandar anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I've been a Gandhi buff for a  long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collins glances at him in surprise as he steers the car a another procession of camels heading toward the port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He certainly makes good copy. (A laugh.) The other day Winston Churchill called  him "that half-naked Indian fakir."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walker smiles too, but it soon passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met him once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collins looks at him in real surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Gandhi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Back in South Africa... (reflectively) long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of hair... and a little like a  college freshman -- trying to figure  everything out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he must've found some of the  answers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He honks as he goes around a wooden-wheeled cart.

dialogues.speaker: PRANAMI TEMPLE
dialogues.text: Simple. Austere. Filtered light. Featuring Gandhi -- clos He is looking straight ahead. Reverse angle. Across the emptiness of the temple, Ba fac him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a step forward) "In every worthy wish of yours, I  shall be your helpmate."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another angle featuring Walker and Collins, who are sitti alone, in the cool shadows of the temple, watching with  fascination as Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage ceremo for them, Walker jotting notes occasionally, but his eyes always glued to Gandhi and Ba, who are in part lost in  memories and echoes of a significance only they can know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a step) "Take a fourth step, that we may be  ever full of joy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide shot. Showing the two of them before the altar of th temple, moving closer to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a step) "I will ever live devoted to you,  speaking words of love and praying  for your happiness."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close shot -- Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Take a fifth step, that we may serve  the people."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I will follow close behind you and  help to serve the people."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring Walker, now too entranced by the ceremony, by t depth of layered emotions in Gandhi and Ba's voices and e to take any notes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Take a sixth step, that we may follow  our vows in life."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I will follow you in all our vows  and duties."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ba and Gandhi. Near to meeting now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a last step) "Take the seventh step, that we may  ever live as friends."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ba takes the last step, so that they are face to face. A  beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You are my best friend... my highest  guru, and my sovereign lord."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment their eyes hold -- the many dreams, and hope and pain -- the love of many years. Walker watches, his own face taut with emotion. Resume Gandhi and Ba. And Gandhi slowly lifts his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I put a sweetened wheat cake in  her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches Ba's lips with his extended fingers and she ki them gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I put a sweetened wheat cake in  his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has lifted her fingers to his mouth and he kisses the gently. Featuring Walker and Collins both touched, the overtly cy American obviously even more than the likeable Englishman Gandhi turns to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that we were pronounced man  and wife. (Solemnly) We were both thirteen...

dialogues.speaker: THE BAY
dialogues.text: A tiny, beautiful city rising steeply out of the Arabian with tall, thick-walled buildings, half-fortresses, half- homes, their white walls tinted amber and gold now by the early light of the sun. Featuring Gandhi, sitting on a promontory watching the su in solemn meditation... He becomes aware of the sound of  footsteps and he turns to see Walker approaching, a littl knapsack over his shoulder. Gandhi smiles. Walker comes t his side, looking out over the bay and city, truly impres

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even as a boy I thought so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walker looks down at him. Gandhi scowls up in the early l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to keep track of you is making  me change all my sleeping habits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you've come all this way because  you think something is going to  happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm. (Then weightedly) Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps. I've come here to think  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both watch the waves beat on the shore a moment, the changing hues of the sunrise on the whites of Porbandar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (musing) Do you remember much of South Africa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've traveled so far -- and thought  so much. (He smiles in self- mockery, and turns  toward the city.) As you can see, my city was a sea  city -- always filled with Hindus  and Muslims and Sikhs and Jews and  Persians. (He looks at Walker.) The temple where you were yesterday  is of my family's sect, the Pranami.  It was Hindu of course but the priests  used to read from the Muslim Koran  and the Hindu Gita, moving from one  to the other as though it mattered  not at all which book was read as  long as God was worshipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks out to sea, and we intercut his face with Walker the sea, and the town itself as the sun turns it white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a boy I used to sing a  song in that temple: "A true disciple  knows another's woes as his own. He  bows to all and despises none...  Earthly possessions hold him not."  Like all boys I said the words, not  thinking of what they meant or how  they might be influencing me. (He looks at Walker...  then out to the sea  again, shaking his  head.) I've traveled so far... and all I've  done is come back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walker studies him as this profound man reaches, in his m years, a profound insight. Featuring Gandhi staring out to sea, his mind locked in  reflection, and suddenly his head lifts, his eyes become  alert, he is caught by some excitement which he weighs fo moment, then he stands, his manner suddenly tingling with optimism. Walker stares at him, then at what Gandhi seems to be loo at. His point of view. The waves lapping the shore below them Walker turns back to Gandhi, puzzled. But there is no  mistaking the sudden glow in Gandhi's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you're going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi looks at him, a teasing smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would have been very uncivil of  me to let you make such a long trip  for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grin broadens, and then he starts briskly down the  promontory. Walker scrambles up after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gulls fly over them, squawking in the growing light. Gand pauses, looking up at the gulls, then back down to the se

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back to the ashram (then firmly) and then I'm going to prove to the  new Viceroy that the King's writ no  longer runs in India!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns from the sea to Walker, his eyes confident, elat then he continues on down the promontory. Still baffled,  Walker glances at the sea, at him, then hurries after. Full shot. The waves running against the shore...

dialogues.speaker: LORD IRWIN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Close shot -- the Viceroy, a "new one," Lord Irwin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another angle. He is looking in astonishment at his princ secretary. His ADC, a general, a brigadier, a senior poli officer are with him. Like him they hold the same offices but are a new team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He is going to march to  the sea and make salt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin looks at him, still trying to penetrate the signifi of the act. The senior police officer helps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a Royal Monopoly on the  manufacture of salt, sir. It's illegal  to make it or sell it without a  Government license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin has listened; it's beginning to make a little sense

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- he's breaking the law.  What will he be depriving us of, two  rupees of salt tax?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a serious attack on the  revenue, sir. Its primary importance  is symbolic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't patronize me, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The principal secretary blanches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. I -- in this climate, sir,  nothing lives without water -- or  salt. Our absolute control of it is  a control on the pulse of India.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin looks at his ADC, then paces a bit, pondering it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's the basis of this  "Declaration of Independence"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The day he sets off everyone  is supposed to raise the flag of  "Free India." Then he walks some two  hundred and forty miles to the sea  and makes salt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment as Irwin considers it, then it is the general wh speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say ignore it. Let them raise their  damn flags, let him make his salt.  It's only symbolic if we choose to  make it so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly) He's going to arrive at the sea on  the anniversary of the massacre at  Amritsar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin has turned to him. And this makes up his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Edgar is right -- ignore it.  Mr. Gandhi will find it's going to  take a great deal more than a pinch  of salt to bring down the British  Empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is concerned enough to be angry, but certain enough to dogmatic.

dialogues.speaker: THE ASHRAM
dialogues.text: It is very early, the light just beginning to break, and are looking out across the river toward the distant town, and against the pink glow of the sky we can see people in groups wading across the river toward the ashram. And sud a mass of people, hidden by the embankment, appear at the top of the steps coming up from the river, and the camera lifts slightly with their movement and we see that they a but the forerunners of a long tendril of humanity that  stretches across the river, all the way back to the dista outskirts of the city. And around the ashram many fires are burning, people are  cooking breakfast, some are packing knapsacks for the jou others are strewing the path from the ashram with leaves.

dialogues.speaker: GANDHI'S BUNGALOW
dialogues.text: Quiet, just the buzz of activity from outside the buildin Gandhi lies on a mat and Ba and Mirabehn are massaging hi with oil as he checks page proofs, an oil lamp by his sid Nehru sits cross-legged next to him, taking the proofs as Gandhi finishes them. Maulana Azad sits to one side. Behi them Desai is making notes on Gandhi's instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nehru) ...the real test will come if I am  arrested. If there is violence we  lose all our moral advantage. This  time it mustn't happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Nehru and Azad solemnly to emphasize the poin Nehru nods; a little smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not beginners anymore. We've  been trained by a strict sergeant  major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means Gandhi of course, and Gandhi accepts the referen but it is the acceptance of the strict sergeant major: "D fail me." Then he looks to Azad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm taken, Maulana is to lead the  march. If he is arrested, Patel,  then Kripalani, then yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru nods. Ba moves to massage the top of Gandhi's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi grins, looking at Mirabehn, who is massaging his l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I'm fit for at least five  hundred miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should ride the pony. It is not  necessary to walk to prove the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi looks at Nehru, a benign shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have two of them bossing me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru smiles. He stands, having taken the last proof shee Azad rises with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must get these to the printer. (He looks down at  Gandhi.) I know it will succeed. Even my mother  is prepared to march.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi is pleasurably impressed with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jinnah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) He's waiting. He's not prepared to  accept it will mean as much as you  think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles confidently) Wait and see... wait and see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans back and closes his eyes. Ba rubs his head  soothingly. Nehru bends and squeezes his arm in farewell. Gandhi nods, not opening his eyes. Nehru and Azad smile a Ba and leave.

dialogues.speaker: THE ASHRAM
dialogues.text: The sun higher, but still early light. A green, white and saffron flag (the colors of India) is pulled up an uneven pole. The sound of gentle clapping. Gandhi is off to one side, just in front of the veranda o his bungalow, not paying attention to the ceremony. Ba an Mirabehn watch from the veranda as Pyarelal (Desai's new  assistant), with a knapsack over his own shoulders, hands Gandhi his. As Gandhi slips it on, the ashramite boy whom saw with the goat hands him a long staff. And Gandhi move around the edge of the bungalow, heading toward the entra of the ashram. A long line of ashramites and marchers stretches from opp the flagpole to the entrance of the ashram. As Gandhi wal briskly along it, they turn, ready to follow him. When he nears the entrance Gandhi sees Walker standing in front of a collection of newsmen, cameramen, a newsreel c He begins to smile, Walker returns it. Gandhi pauses by h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of the press) You've done me a great service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a grin, then a play  on Gandhi's words to  him) It would have been uncivil of me to  have let you make such a long trip  for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi smiles. He turns back toward his bungalow. Ba and  Mirabehn stand there watching, Desai with them. Gandhi ho their gaze a second, then turns and starts forward. Pyare takes up a position next to him, the marchers follow. Featuring Walker. He steps back, letting Gandhi proceed i the range of the cameras on his own. The crowd around the entrance throws flowers in Gandhi's path, some calling ou "Long live Mahatma Gandhi!" Gandhi passes the cameramen and starts along the trail.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATH TO GANDHI'S ASHRAM
dialogues.text: A thinner crowd here, but going all along the path. To on side we see two police cars drawn up, and several policem (a British officer, a British sergeant, and four Indian  constables) lined up near them. As Gandhi nears them Walker moves up beside him. Some of newspaper cameramen trot behind to get the picture of Gan arrest. Among the newsmen we see Collins. Featuring Gandhi and Walker, Pyarelal just behind them al glancing ahead at the police, who are now quite near.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it over if they arrest you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if they arrest me -- or a thousand --  or ten thousand. (He looks at Walker.) It is not only generals who know how  to plan campaigns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walker smiles -- a little uneasily -- for they are now ne the police. Gandhi nods to them amiably as he passes alon in front of them. Walker is turning, watching for a move  from the police but begins to grasp that there may be non He hurries along closer to Gandhi again, one eye still on the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if they don't arrest you? What  if they don't react at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi glances at him. Walker too wears a knapsack. Gandh nods to it, though never breaking his pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still have your notebook? (Walker fumbles for  it; Gandhi goes right  on talking.) The function of a civil resister is  to provoke response. And we will  continue to provoke until they  respond, or they change the law.  They are not in control -- we are.  That is the strength of civil  resistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods politely toward the British police officer at the end of the police line. Walker stops, letting the process march on by him, looking at the British police officer, t writing busily in his notebook. Collins stop by him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) He said he's in charge...

dialogues.speaker: AN INDIAN VILLAGE
dialogues.text: A dusty approach to a dusty little village. Both sides of the track are lined with peasants holding flower petals a leaves, all gazing expectantly down the road. Behind them the village is strung with the green, white and saffron c of Independence. Two large policemen stand arms-akimbo at the front of the all, their postures imposing and threatening, though the  impression is somewhat weakened by the children skirting  around them. A little band of drummers and flute players suddenly begi to play. The crowd starts to jump up to see, and the flow petals begin to float in the sky. "Gandhi! Long live Maha Gandhi!" Another angle. Gandhi and the procession of marchers and  ashramites stride down the dusty road toward them. A newsreel truck and crew ride along about two-thirds of way back. A car of cameramen and reporters tails at the e Featuring Gandhi. He looks at Walker, walking along a few paces behind him, at the side of the procession. He is wi sweat from his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to walk all the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a weary grin) My name is Walk-er. And I intend to  report it the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi smiles and turns back. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) "My name is Walk-er"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And grinning at it, he passes by the policemen and into t cheers of the crowd. Long shot, high. As the procession trails into the villag we see several villagers, knapsacks or bundles strung ove their shoulders, run around the police and join the end o the procession.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD BY THE ROAD
dialogues.text: In the dark a large group of students comes stumbling,  laughing, across the ditch that separates the road from t field. The student leader gets clear of the ditch and com upon Pyarelal and Walker. They are standing near a group American newsmen playing poker by a campfire. He addresse Pyarelal good-naturedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've come to join the march. What  do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bluntly) Be sure you're awake in the morning. (It comes from a  knowledge of students.  He smiles and nods  off.) Find a place to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The student leader follows his gaze and the camera pans o with his glance. We see that the numbers have grown immen Fires dot the field and spread and spread and spread. Beh Walker and Pyarelal the newsreel truck and three cars for reporters are spread out around the fires. We identify a  couple of Frenchmen and a Japanese. Walker looks at Pyare and shakes his head in wonder at it all.

dialogues.speaker: TREE
dialogues.text: A small Indian boy is high in a dead tree. Below him a co of bone-thin cattle graze in the early light as he stares off.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTY ROAD
dialogues.text: The huge procession stretched out along the road. Resume the boy. He grins as though he is privy to some gr secret.

dialogues.speaker: "Y" JUNCTION OF TWO COUNTRY ROADS
dialogues.text: A blunt, rotund, powerful-looking woman (Sarojini Naidu) an outrageously colorful sari strides along the dusty roa as though she could cover another thousand miles -- and m to. The sound of hundreds of marching feet, of cars, some distant singing. The camera lifts and pulls back. We see  that Naidu is marching just behind Gandhi, like a determi lieutenant, and that the procession has grown even greate Two newsreel trucks now, four cars of reporters, some peo riding donkeys, some walking with camels trailing, loaded with belongings. And at the "Y" junctions the newsreel crews suddenly go i action because another enormous procession is waiting to  join the first, mingling already, making one immense colu of humanity. And as they pass the camera up close we see an extraordin variety of participants: old, young, students, peasants,  ladies in saris and jewels, Muslims, Hindus, Sikhs, Chris nuns, Untouchables, merchants, some vigorous and determin others disheveled, tired and determined. Suddenly the sound of waves and gentle wind.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEACH AT DANDI
dialogues.text: The camera closing fast (helicopter) as the silhouette of man appears running up a sand dune, lifting his arms to t sky and the camera sweeps over him and up, revealing a  crescent of beach and ocean, and for a second it holds on the sea as it did at Porbandar, then pivots to the truly  astronomical crowd thronging the shore, an immense wheel human beings, and in its hub a gathering around Gandhi. W descend on that center, recognizing the newsmen, Walker,  Pyarelal, Sarojini Naidu, and at last Gandhi picking up a handful of natural salt and lifting it high. During the last of this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man needs salt as he needs air and  water. This salt comes from the Indian  Ocean. (The salt crystals  are added to an urn  already partially  full. The camera  pulls back and Gandhi  lifts the urn. All  around him the  pressing crowd:  newsreel cameramen,  reporters -- Walker,  Collins, Naidu,  Pyarelal. Firmly) Let every Indian claim it as his  right!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide-angle shot. Gandhi in the center of the wildly cheering crowd, the ca pulling back and back... and the shot becomes black and w and we hear the music of Movietone News.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and so once more the man of non- violence has challenged the might of  the British Empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that we get the Movietone Music tag and as the f fades, the lights go up on

dialogues.speaker: LORD IRWIN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: A couple of civil servants move about to raise the window shades while Lord Irwin stares at the blank screen set up his office. The general, the brigadier, the senior police officer, Irwin's ADC and the principal secretary are all  present. The two men who ran the projector are quietly  dismantling it. Finally, Irwin turns to the senior police officer, who  fidgets, but answers the implied questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're making it everywhere, sir --  mobs of them -- publicly. Congress  leaders are selling it on the streets  of Delhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're being made fools of around the  world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there any instruction from  London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're required to stop it. (He stands, his mind  made up.) And stop it we will. (He looks at the senior  police officer.) I don't care if we fill the jails,  stop it. Arrest anyone, any rank --  except Gandhi. We'll cut his strength  from under him. And then we'll deal  with the Mahatma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time he is truly angry.

dialogues.speaker: WALL BY A BEACH
dialogues.text: A young British subaltern trots up to the wall and looks  down. His face falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beach. Subaltern's point of view. Packed with people  making salt, selling salt, buying salt. Resume the British subaltern. He looks back. His point of view. Behind him there is an open military t and about twenty sepoys. Formidable for an ordinary crowd nothing to handle this. The subaltern stiffens bravely an signals the men somewhat unconvincingly from the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right -- jump to it -- clear this  beach!

dialogues.speaker: SMALL WAREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Men, women and children are making little paper packets o salt from piles heaped along long tables. A group of poli barge into the room, knocking tables and salt and paper i every direction with their lathis, seizing some of the  volunteers for arrest. In the chaos an old man calmly picks up a piece of paper  from the floor, a handful of salt, and folds another pack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru is on the back of a big open truck that is stationa in the street. The truck is loaded with boxes that contai salt packets and Nehru and eight or nine others are selli them to people who flock about the truck. The sound of ho Nehru lifts his head. Mounted Indian police are coming down either side of the  street, a wave of foot police running forward down the ce Some of the people run, others deliberately stand fast. The mounted police converge on the truck. Nehru is grabbe and hurled so that he half falls, half leaps to the stree One of the men with him is knocked along the ground by a  policeman. He is young and vigorous and he swivels on the ground as though to strike back. Nehru lunges toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No violence, Zia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a lathi is brought smashing across the side of Nehru' head. He is knocked to his knees; blood streams from his  head. He feels the side of his head, the blood soaking hi hand. He struggles to his feet, facing the policeman who struck him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating quietly,  as though to Zia) ...no violence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stops the policeman for a second, and a sergeant sudde intrudes, recognizing Nehru.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Nehru --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an illegal trader in salt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sergeant sighs grimly.

dialogues.speaker: LORD IRWIN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The desk lights are on. Irwin, the senior police officer, the principal secretary. Tension, fatigue, frustration as the senior police officer outlines the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...There's been no time to keep  figures, but there must be ninety --  a hundred thousand under arrest. (Grimly, incredibly) And it still goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Who's leading them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! Nehru, Patel, almost  every Congress Official is in jail...  and their wives and their children --  we've even arrested Nehru's mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrewdly) Has there been any violence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted, offhand) Oh, in Karachi the police fired on a  crowd and killed a couple of people  and -- (and this hurts) and in Peshawar the Deputy Police  Commissioner lost his head and...  and opened fire with a machine gun. (He looks up at them  quickly, defensively.) But he's facing a disciplinary court!  You can't expect things like that  not to happen when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) I believe the question was intended  to discover if there was any violence  of their side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The senior police officer looks up, realizing his gaffe a wishes desperately he could relive the last couple of min

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, sir -- no, I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again the  Machiavellian mind) Perhaps if we arrested Gandhi, it  might --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means incite violence. The Viceroy ponders it -- favor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to senior police  officer) He's addressed this letter directly  to you, has he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, he has. The usual -- India's  salt belongs to India -- but then he  says flatly that he personally is  going to lead a raid tomorrow on the  Dharasana Salt Works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Thank him for his letter, and put  him in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The senior police officer is brought up by the chill  directness of it. He looks at Irwin and the principal  secretary for a moment in uncertainty. Then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Yes, sir. It will be my  pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns to leave Irwin speaks -- almost offhandedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Fields, keep that salt works  open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The senior police officer stares at him, then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: DHARASANA SALT WORKS
dialogues.text: Barbed wire stretches on either side of the stockade-like entrance. Above the gate we see the sign DHARASANA SALT W Before it six British police officers and two Indian poli officers command a large troop of Indian policemen. They  face their opposition, unmoving, tense. The camera pans f them, across a sloping dip in the ground, to a huge group volunteers lining up to face the police as tautly as the  police face them. Walker is off to one side, climbing to stand in the back Collin's car. He watches, looking tensely from one group the other, almost terrified by what seems about to happen Collins leans against the back of the car near him, watch with an equally appalled expectancy. There are two other  reporters near them. From Walker's point of view. We see Mirabehn and some Ind women quietly placing stretchers and tables of bandages n a group of tents where the volunteers have been housed. Walker turns back to the two opposing groups at the Salt  Works entrance. We hear only a shuffle of feet, the clank a lathi against a metal police buckle. The air itself see breathless with tension. Featuring Azad. He has approached the chief police office He stops before him politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like admission to the Works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (equally politely) I am sorry, sir. That cannot be  allowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
