dialogues.text: Azad looks at him a second, then glances at the troops. H is clearly afraid, but there is an air of tragic inevitab in his face. He moves back to address the volunteers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night they took Gandhiji from  us. They expect us to lose heart or  to fight back. We will not lose heart,  we will not fight back. In his name  we will be beaten. As he has taught  us, we will not raise a hand. "Long  live Mahatma Gandhi!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and starts down the dip toward the gate and the  waiting lathis of the police. A series of shots, as Azad leads the first row of volunte down and up the dip. We intercut Walker, frozen, watching the inevitable onsla the British police commanding officer ready to give the f order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with the volunteers a foot from them, the police stri with their lathis. A groan of empathic anguish from the  waiting volunteers, but then we get A series of shots As next row moves forward and the horror of the one-sided ma proceeds heads are cracked, faces split, ribs smashed, an yet one row of volunteers follows another, and another in the unrelenting police, who knock bleeding bodies out of way, down into the dip, swing till sweat pours from their faces and bodies. And through it we intercut with Mirabehn and the Indian w rescuing the wounded, carrying them on stretchers to be  bandaged. We see Walker helping once or twice, turning,  watching, torn between being a professional spectator and normal human being. And always the volunteers coming, nev stopping, never offering resistance. And finally on sound there is an insistent click, click,  click, like a thud of the lathis but becoming clearly the slap of an impatient hand on a telephone cradle and out o the carnage of the salt works we dissolve to

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL INDIAN STORE
dialogues.text: Close shot -- a telephone cradle being pounded. Walker is at the phone at a table in the corner of the sm cluttered store. His clothes are matted with blood and di

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Hello! Ed! Ed! Goddammit, don't cut  me off! (Then suddenly he's  through.) Ed! Okay -- yeah -- right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he continues urgently reading the story that lies on notes on the little stand before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "They walked, with heads up, without  music, or cheering, or any hope of  escape from injury or death." (His voice is taut,  harshly professional.) "It went on and on and on. Women  carried the wounded bodies from the  ditch until they dropped from  exhaustion. But still it went on."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shifts the mangled notes and comes to his last paragra He speaks it trying only half successfully to keep the em from his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Whatever moral ascendance the West  held was lost today. India is free  for she has taken all that steel and  cruelty can give, and she has neither  cringed nor retreated." (On Walker close. His  sweating, blood and  dirt-stained face  near tears.) "In the words of his followers, 'Long  live Mahatma Gandhi.' "

dialogues.speaker: LORD IRWIN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Silence. The camera moves across the empty room and disco Irwin, standing by himself, looking out of the window dow into the street. Closer. His numb, motionless face is stirred to conscious by something outside. He focuses somberly on it.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: Through the formal entrance comes a single black car. A  motorcycle policeman precedes it.

dialogues.speaker: VICE-REGAL PALACE
dialogues.text: The black car pulls up before the front of the palace and stops. There is no sign of activity. It is as though the  building and grounds are deserted except for Irwin alone his office. Gandhi gets out of the car. He too is alone. In his dhoti and shawl he starts to mount the grand stairs. Wide angle. The great palace, the magnificent entrance, a the little man in the dhoti, who in a sense has conquered all, marching to the great doors. Two Gurkhas spring to  attention and the doors are swung open.

dialogues.speaker: LORD IRWIN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The principal secretary, with a look of faint distaste fo someone out of shot, discreetly moves out of the doors, a closes them behind him. Featuring Gandhi, just inside the door. He is looking acr the wide office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am aware that I must have given  you much cause for irritation, your  Excellency. I hope it will not stand  between us as men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverse angle. Irwin is in shadows behind his desk lookin still, in some kind of shock, staring at Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gandhi, I have instructions to  request your attendance at an All- Government Conference in London to  discuss -- to discuss the possible  Independence of India.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He faces Gandhi stiffly. The whirr of a camera, and a swift cut to

dialogues.speaker: GANDHI'S VISIT TO ENGLAND AND THE ALL-GOVERNMENT CONFEREN
dialogues.text: Wide screen, but slightly under-cranked with the bad cutt and predictable music of the old newsreels. A. Gandhi, Mirabehn and Gandhi's secretary, Desai, waving goodbye from the boat deck of their ship as it sails --  Mirabehn is holding the tether of a goat -- all of them  smiling at the camera like voyagers everywhere. B. Gandhi on the steps of Kingsley Hall in the East End o London being greeted by a cheering crowd. Mirabehn holds umbrella over him as he takes a bouquet from a little chi The now gray-haired Charlie Andrews beams possessively at his side. C. Gandhi, in his dhoti, waving to a small crowd as he en the gates of Buckingham Palace. A London bobby watches. D. Gandhi, taking his seat at the conference table among formally -- in some Maharajahs' cases, elaborately -- dre delegates. A gavel is struck and Ramsay MacDonald begins opening address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think our first duty is to recognize  that there is not one India, but  several: a Hindu India, a Muslim  India, and India of Princely States.  And all these must be respected --  and cared for -- not just one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beneath its unctuous political veneer it is blatantly div and clearly reveals the true intent of the Conference. As Gandhi looks at MacDonald, we read on his face his percep of the sad truth. E. Gandhi, Mirabehn and Charlie walking under an umbrella the rain, their heads bent in glum conversation. F. Gandhi being welcomed and kissed by a group of millwor outside a large mill entrance identified by the sign  GREENFIELD COTTON MILL, LANCASHIRE. He is hugged and sque by some hefty female millworkers, all grinning happily, G not least. G. Gandhi in a radio studio, seated at a table, a large  microphone labeled "CBS" before him, technicians and Mira in the glass booth behind him, Walker across the table fr him, the "On the Air" sign bright...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Walker) Do I speak into that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walker cringes, glancing at the lighted "On the Air" sign He signals "Yes" frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they ready? Do I start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at the booth. Everybody including Walker and  Mirabehn are nodding "Yes." Gandhi shrugs, grins at every excitement, and begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am glad to speak to America where  so many friends exist that I know  only in my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the speech continues in the thin, static-y tones of  thirties' radio, we see Mirabehn and the technicians list in the control room./ Walker, across the table from Gandh The outside of Broadcasting House./ The Empire State Buil and Manhattan./ A mid-western farmhouse./ A thirties' rad set in a thirties' American living room./ A family, liste kids playing on the floor, half ignoring it, the mother  ironing, the father in an armchair, a newspaper open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing over all) I think your interest and the world's  has fallen on India, not only because  we are struggling for freedom, but  because the way we are doing so is  unique as far as history shows us.  Here in Europe mighty nations are,  it seems, already contemplating  another war, though I think they,  and all the world, are sick to death  of bloodspilling. All of us are  seeking a way out, and I flatter  myself that perhaps the ancient land  of India will offer such a way. If  we are to make progress we must not  repeat history, but make history.  And I myself will die before I betray  our belief that love is a stronger  weapon than hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H. Gandhi shaking hands with MacDonald outside No. 10 Dow Street, MacDonald smiling the politician's smile, Gandhi  smiling rather sadly. I. Gandhi on the deck of a boat, sitting on a deck chair, wrapped in blankets, staring somberly out to sea. Reverse angle: the wake of the boat in the vast ocean.

dialogues.speaker: THE ASHRAM
dialogues.text: The gentle sounds of the country. A girl of twelve leads limping goat slowly across the grass. She pauses and look up questioningly. Reverse angle -- close. Gandhi is watching from the porch his bungalow. We can tell he is sitting and turned to wat the goat, but we see only him and a portion of the bungal behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is only a sprain. Take her to the  river, and we'll make a mud-pack for  her. Go -- I won't be long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back. Another angle. He is spinning (expertly), and gathered on the porch with him are Nehru and Jinnah and Patel and Aza and Kripalani. Desai and Pyarelal are inconspicuously in  attendance as always, Pyarelal now clearly sharing Desai' role as secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the truth is, after all your  travels, all your efforts, they've  stopped the campaign and sent you  home empty-handed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in his white suit, the black-ribboned pince-nez. He sits on a wicker chair, Nehru and Patel lean against the  railing, Azad and Kripalani sit on the floor like Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are only clinging to old dreams (looks up from his  spinning to Jinnah) and trying to split us in the old  way. But the will has gone --  Independence will drop like a ripe  apple. The only question is when (another glance at  Jinnah) and how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say when is now -- and we will  determine how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precisely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi winds up what he has done, and starts to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are preparing for war. I will  not support it, but I do not intend  to take advantage of their danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blithely, but to the  point) That's when you take advantage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi has moved toward the steps. He stops and looks at  Patel. A wry, gentle smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That is just another way of  striking back. We have come a long  way together with the British. When  they leave we want to see them off  as friends. (He starts down the  steps and heads for  the river.) And now, if you'll excuse me, there  is something I must attend to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring Nehru. He looks at Jinnah and shrugs. Jinnah ta it less philosophically and his eyes burn with anger as h watches Gandhi head for the young girl with the injured g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resignedly) "Mud packs."

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN STATION. INTERIOR. DUSK.
dialogues.text: Gandhi is moving with the stream of passengers disembarki from the Third Class section. Ba and Mirabehn are struggl along behind him, Desai and Pyarelal completing the littl group. They pass a newspaper stand: "Hitler's Armies Swee On." As they move out into the flux of the station we see many uniforms, the sense of a nation readying for war. A British captain stands before a full platoon of Indian  troops. As Gandhi approaches, a British Lt. Colonel and his Adjut (a Captain) move out from one side of the troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gandhi -- sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi stops, looks up at him, at the troops behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have instructions to inquire as to  the subject of your speech tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi shakes his head with a weary grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The value of goat's milk in daily  diet. (Into his eyes) But you can be sure I will also speak  against war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The British Colonel signals back to the troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. That can't be allowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a detail marches up to them, the colonel's adjutant sp gently to Ba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Mrs. Gandhi. I have  orders to return with you and your  companion to the Mahatma's ashram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you take my husband, I intend to  speak in his place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at the adjutant belligerently. He looks flummo Later. Long shot -- high. The colonel and his adjutant  striding toward the exit of the station. Following behind them, a detail of six soldiers accompanying Gandhi. The c tracks across the platform and we see they are being foll by a detail of six soldiers accompanying Ba. And the came tracks again and we see they are being followed by a deta of six soldiers accompanying Mirabehn!

dialogues.speaker: WINDING BUMPY ROAD
dialogues.text: A jeep bounces along the road. It is driven by an America lieutenant and his passenger is a woman dressed in an Ame War Correspondent's uniform (Margaret Bourke-White). As t jeep passes the camera we pan with it and see the walls o palace ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jeep slithers to a stop, and Bourke-White grabs a cam that is strapped around her, stands, and takes a picture the palace.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The palace looks evocative -- a lonely, incongruous build

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the Aga Khan's palace, but  they've turned it into a prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourke-White slips back down into her seat; we see the ar band on her jacket: "Press." The lieutenant starts the je up and they head toward the gate, where we see a British  soldier on guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting over the  motor) They've got most of the leading  Congress politicians in this one.  But Nehru and some others are over  in Dehra Dun. Your timing's pretty  lucky. They had your Mr. Gandhi cut  off from the press but last month  his personal secretary died and  they've let up on the restrictions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourke-White just absorbs it, staring at the palace, taki in the experience with the appetite of her breed, and her own particular sensitivity.

dialogues.speaker: GANDHI'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Gandhi sits by the window that is grilled rather than bar He is spinning in a shaft of light -- and looking off -- we hear a camera click and the rustle of movement. His ha only half-gray in London, is now white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have heard of Life Magazine. (A smile.) I have even heard of Margaret Bourke- White. But I don't know why either  should be interested in an old man  sitting in prison when the world is  blowing itself to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourke-White -- who has been moving, crouching to shoot h and the light -- sags back against the wall, relaxing at  last. She has a smile as penetrating and warming as his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat -- and she  smiles) You're the only man I know who makes  his own clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi grins and glances toward his dhoti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, but for me that's not much of an  accomplishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning he doesn't wear many clothes. Bourke-White bursts into an appreciative radiance -- already she has assessed him, and been won.

dialogues.speaker: WALL AND YARD
dialogues.text: Gandhi walks along, Bourke-White loping along beside him, little distance away, listening, but searching too for an angle, a moment that is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- prison is rather agreeable to  me, and there is no doubt that after  the war, independence will come. My  only worry is what shape it will  take. Jinnah has --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has Gandhi in the foreground, a soldier on the wall a and behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now go on -- just as you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi shrugs but suffers it. We feature him, low, from h point of view, as he walks on, the soldier pacing on the  wall in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coaching) "...what shape it will take." Jinnah  has -- what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at first disconcerted,  but then flowing) Jinnah has -- has cooperated with  the British. It has given him power  and the freedom to speak, and he has  filled the Muslims with fears of  what will happen to them in a country  that is predominantly Hindu. (He stops, lowering  his head gravely.) That I find hard to bear -- even in  prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She clicks.

dialogues.speaker: WALLED GARDEN IN THE PALACE
dialogues.text: A spinning wheel works rapidly. The camera lifts. Gandhi at the wheel and he is smiling off at Bourke-White, who i trying ineptly to imitate him on another spinning wheel. garden they are in has gone to seed a bit, but with latti fretwork in the walls dappling sunlight on the grass and  shrubs it is still beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (archly, but  emphatically of the  spinning) I do not see it as the solution of  the twentieth century's problems!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's grinning at her own frustration and she keeps tryin but there's no doubt she means it. Gandhi's smile broaden Wryly he lifts his own "product" -- a tiny roll of thread

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a friend who keeps telling me  how much it costs him to keep me in  poverty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they both laugh... a guard on the wall distantly look at them wonderingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit more seriously) But I know happiness does not come  with things -- even twentieth century  things. It can come from work, and  pride in what you do. (He looks at her  steadily.) It will not necessarily be "progress"  for India if she simply imports the  unhappiness of the West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she responds to the sophistication of that observatio He pivots around, moving beside her, and slowly demonstra the process, taking her hands, guiding her. Bourke-White  watches him as much as the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But do you really believe you could  use non-violence against someone  like Hitler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a thoughtful pause) Not without defeats -- and great  pain. (He looks at her.) But are there no defeats in this war --  no pain? (For a moment the  thought hangs, and  then Gandhi takes  their hands back to  the spinning.) What you cannot do is accept  injustice. From Hitler -- or anyone.  You must make the injustice visible --  be prepared to die like a soldier to  do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he smiles a little wisely at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is my finger supposed to be wrapped  around that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) No. That is what you get for  distracting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you expect when you talk  like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to unravel  the mess) I expect you to show as much patience  as I am now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His tone is not altogether patient. She looks at him in  surprise and he sighs tolerantly. Then reflectively

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every enemy is a human being -- even  the worst of them. And he believes  he is right and you are a beast. (And now a little  smile.) And if you beat him over the head  you will only convince him. But you  suffer, to show him that he is wrong,  your sacrifice creates an atmosphere  of understanding -- if not with him,  then in the hearts of the rest of  the community on whom he depends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourke-White looks at him and there is enough sense in th argument to give her pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you are right, you will win --  after much pain. (He looks at her,  then smiles in his  own ironic way.) If you are wrong, well, then, only  you will suffer the blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him, and we know she thinks him much more  profound than she had thought initially.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ba, Mirabehn and Bourke-White sit on straw mats around th room, an oil lamp is the only light. It is women's talk, Ba is defending her husband, speaking simply, but with to conviction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...not at all. Bapu has always said  there were two kinds of slavery in  India -- one for women, one for the  untouchables -- and he has always  fought against both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourke-White accepts it at face value. She opens another  line of inquiry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it rankle, being separated from  him this way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ba pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... but we see each other in the  day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delicately) But not at night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's terribly curious, but she doesn't want to offend. B sees both the curiosity and the hesitancy. She smiles acr at Mirabehn, then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Hindu philosophy the way to God  is to free yourself of possessions --  and the passions that inflame to  anger and jealousy. (A smile.) Bapu has always struggled to find  the way to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean he -- he gave up -- (how to phrase it,  finally) married life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again Ba smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four times he tried -- and failed. (Mirabehn and Bourke- White grin. The older  woman gives a wistful  smile.) But then he took a solemn vow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrugs... the implication is it was a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he has never broken it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at them soberly and then they all burst into  laughter like girls.

dialogues.speaker: AGA KHAN'S PALACE
dialogues.text: Military move quietly but urgently in and out around the  main entrance. Two military ambulances are drawn up nearb A British major comes down the steps quickly. He is almos at the bottom when a British army doctor starts to go up  them. The major signals him to one side. They talk quietl and confidentially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got permission to move her --  he can go too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's had a coronary throm -- a  serious heart failure. She wouldn't  survive a trip. It's best to leave  her -- and hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The major looks defeated and depressed by the news.

dialogues.speaker: BA'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Ba lies on a mat, a pillow beneath her head, her eyes clo her breathing short. Mirabehn sits next to her, rubbing a hand up and down her arm. Gandhi sits a little distance away, staring at the floor into nothingness. Pyarelal sits inconspicuously behind hi Azad and Patel come to the doorway, Patel makes the prana toward Ba and holds it as he obviously prays. Azad has bo his head and he too is clearly making some prayer for her Finally Azad takes just a step forward. Gandhi looks up at him. For a moment he folds his hands  absently, then he stands. He moves to Ba's side and kneel She does not open her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is time for my walk -- I won't be  long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ba's eyes flutter open. She holds her hand out to him and takes it. When he goes to release it, she clutches it. Ga hesitates, and then he sits, holding Ba's hand in his lap He looks across at Mirabehn and nods for her to go. Mirabehn smiles weakly, gives Ba a last little rub of far and stands. The doorway. Patel stands, letting Mirabehn pass before h and do down the corridor with Azad. He looks back. His point of view. Gandhi sitting, holding Ba's hand, his eyes once more on the floor in their empty stare. Another angle -- later. The light has changed. A fly move along a small section of the floor that still contains a  ribbon of the dying sunlight. Gandhi still sits, holding Ba's hand, staring into  nothingness. The doctor appears in the doorway. He pauses, nods amiabl to Gandhi, though Gandhi does not react to his presence a all. Moving quietly, the doctor goes to the other side of and crouches, and lifts her wrist to feel her pulse. He h it for a moment, then lifts his eyes in doubt and sudden  fateful apprehension. He glances at her, then slowly lowe her arm and puts the branches of his stethoscope in his e He puts the acoustic bell over her heart... a moment, and lifts it slowly, his face confirming for us what he and w already know: there is no heartbeat. He glances at Pyarel who only lowers his eyes. The doctor turns his head slowl to Gandhi. Gandhi. His point of view. His posture is utterly unchang Ba's hand still in his lap, his eyes still staring emptil at the floor in front of him, but suddenly tears begin to run down his cheeks. He does not move, there is no change his empty stare, but the tears continue to flow.

dialogues.speaker: SMALL COURTYARD OF THE PALACE
dialogues.text: The funeral pyre burns, its work almost done. Mirabehn, Patel, Azad, Pyarelal, stand with other prisone and the military wardens in solemn obeisance to the dead and the living, for Gandhi sits a little distance from th pyre, wrapped in his shawl, staring at the dying embers i tragic and impenetrable isolation as though he may never  move again. Close shot -- Mirabehn watching him her face wet with tea

dialogues.speaker: DELHI AIRPORT
dialogues.text: Extreme close shot. A piece of cloth, shimmering in a sti breeze... For a moment we hold it in silence and then we  hear the sound of an aircraft growing louder and louder. slowly the camera pulls back and we see that the cloth is part of a pennant of the nose of an aircraft. We cut from the pennant to see the aircraft stopping befo a reception area, a carpet rolled out toward its door. An Indian regimental band strikes up martial music. A  detachment of Indian Royal Air Force comes to attention a the shouted command of their NCO. Featuring the aircraft doors. An elaborately dressed mili aide opens the door and Lord Louis Mountbatten, resplende in naval uniform, steps out onto the platform. He pauses renders a salute.

dialogues.speaker: ON A BANNERED PLATFORM
dialogues.text: Nehru, Lady Mountbatten and dignitaries. English and Indi watch as Mountbatten approaches a group of microphones  identified as NBC, CBS, BBC, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have come to crown victory with  friendship -- to assist at the birth  of an independent India and to welcome  her as an equal member in the British  Commonwealth of Nations. (A little smile.) I am here to see that I am the last  British Viceroy ever to have the  honor of such a reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grins in his youthful, beguiling manner and makes the  pranam to the cheering crowd. It is cut off by the sound of a door being opened, close.

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT PORTICO
dialogues.text: Jinnah stands by one of the great pillars of the immense  portico. It is a break in their Independence Conference, as he lights a cigarette, a weary Gandhi approaches him w Azad. Jinnah's anger is clearly too deep to be left at th conference table. He slaps his lighter shut and addresses Gandhi in hushed but fiercely felt words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn for the  independence of India! I am concerned  about the slavery of Muslims!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru and Patel are approaching from the conference room, both of them looking worn and angry too. Jinnah raises hi voice deliberately so Nehru will hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not sit by to see the mastery  of the British replaced by the mastery  of the Hindus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently, not yet  believing it can't  be settled) Muslim and Hindu are the right and  left eye of India. No one will be  slave, no one master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jinnah sneers at the idea, though he cools a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is not made of Mahatma  Gandhis. (He looks at Nehru  and Patel.) I am talking about the real world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "real India" has Muslims and  Hindus in every village and every  city! How do you propose to separate  them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where there is a Muslim majority --  that will be Pakistan. The rest is  your India.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a forced patience) Mohammed -- the Muslims are in a  majority on two different sides of  the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acidly) Let us worry about Pakistan -- you  worry about India.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi is staring at Jinnah trying to fathom the source o his anger and fear. He turns to see that Mountbatten has  been standing in the open door to the conference room, as torn as Gandhi by the conflict, feeling it best controlle in formal discussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, perhaps we should  recommence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi nods, and reluctantly the adversaries move back to the conference room. Gandhi is last through the door. He  pauses by Mountbatten, a little sigh -- "How difficult, h difficult" -- then he puts a friendly hand on Mountbatten shoulder and the two of them enter together.

dialogues.speaker: GANDHI'S ASHRAM
dialogues.text: Featuring Godse waving a black flag and shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with others) Death to Jinnah! Death to Jinnah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have pulled back and we see a whole gathering of Hindu youths near the entrance to the ashram. Many wave black f A couple of trucks that have brought them, and a car, are along the path. Kallenbach is stepping out of an old 1942 open Austin that he has put in a waiting position near th entrance to the path. The chanting shout "Death to Jinnah suddenly dies. The youths -- and Kallenbach -- look back  toward the ashram. Featuring Gandhi's bungalow. Nehru has stepped out onto t porch and he glares at the youths. It is his presence tha has silenced them. Kallenbach smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GANDHI'S BUNGALOW
dialogues.text: Gandhi is rising from the floor, where his spinning wheel sits. He stops, halfway up, listening, then, a weary sigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God, they've stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn is spinning across the room. She lifts her head a signal to someone out of shot. Gandhi's two grand nieces, Manu and Abha, who help Mirabe now that Ba is gone, rise quickly at Mirabehn's signal, M to help with his shawl, Abha to hold his sandals so that can slip into them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your grand uncle but I can still  walk either of you into the ground  and I don't need to be pampered this  way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cross -- he's worried about other things. Mirabehn j smiles at it. Gandhi looks down at Abha, and taps her sha on the top of the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish your quota of spinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods obediently, the flicker of a smile around her mo youthful, irrepressible. The beauty of it almost saddens  Gandhi. He taps her again -- gently -- and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: GANDHI'S ASHRAM
dialogues.text: Kallenbach shoos a chicken from the back seat of the Aust and dusts off the seat. He steps back out. Gandhi is approaching with Nehru and Azad, Pyarelal trail close behind. We have seen Azad and Pyarelal come out on porch behind Nehru. As Gandhi near the car a Hindu youth  with a black flag calls to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu -- please. Don't do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all awed, timid even in his actual presence, and the mood of their gathering has changed altogether. Gandh looks at the youth and the line of others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) What do you want me not to do? Not  to meet with Mr. Jinnah? (Fiercely) I am a Muslim! (He stares at them,  then relents.) And a Hindu, and a Christian and a  Jew -- and so are all of you. When  you wave those flags and shout you  send fear into the hearts of your  brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sweeps them sternly with his eyes, all his fatigue and strain showing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the India I want. Stop  it. For God's sake, stop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he lowers his head and moves on to the car, where  Kallenbach holds the door for him, Nehru, Azad and Pyarel following. Another angle. As they get into the car, we see the car t sits by the two trucks that have brought the youths. In t back seat we see two men, one of whom is Prakash (The bea man at Gandhi's assassination).

dialogues.speaker: JINNAH'S DRAWING ROOM
dialogues.text: Jinnah is on the small balcony of this elaborate room. He looking down in a slightly supercilious manner. As usual is impeccably dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, please, if you've finished your  prayers, could we begin with business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has been looking at Gandhi, who sits on the floor of t large room some distance from him, just lifting his head  from prayers. Nehru, Patel and Azad are on the same side of the room as Gandhi. They rise from prayer as Jinnah comes down the st to them. Gandhi hesitates, then begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Jinnah, you and I are brothers  born of the same Mother India. If  you have fears, I want to put them  to rest. (Jinnah listens  impatiently,  skeptically. Gandhi  just glances in  Nehru's direction.) I am asking Panditji to stand down.  I want you to be the first Prime  Minister of India (Jinnah raises an  eyebrow of interest.) -- to name your entire cabinet, to  make the head of every government  department a Muslim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jinnah has drawn himself up. His vanity is too great to be touched by that prospect. He measures Gandhi for a  moment to see that he is sincere, and when he is satisfie with that, he turns slowly to Nehru, Patel and Azad. Nehru glances at Patel. They have all been taken by surpr by the offer -- and do not feel what Gandhi feels. Nehru  looks hesitantly at Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu, for me, and the rest, (his hand gestures to  Patel and Azad) if that is what you want, we will  accept it. But out there (he indicates the  streets) already there is rioting because  Hindus fear you are going to give  too much away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you did this, no one could control  it. No one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It bears the stamp of undeniable truth. Gandhi's eyes sag with the despair of a man whose last hope, whose faith, h crumbled around him. Jinnah smiles cynically, he spreads his hands "See?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is your choice. Do you want an  independent India and an independent  Pakistan? Or do you want civil war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi stares at him numbly.

dialogues.speaker: THE RED FORT
dialogues.text: On a platform in the foreground Mountbatten and Nehru. A  band plays the Indian National Anthem loudly and there is the roar of a tremendous crowd as the green, white and sa flag of India is raised on the flagpole.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNMENT BUILDING
dialogues.text: On a platform in the foreground Jinnah and a British  plenipotentiary. A band plays the new Pakistani National  Anthem loudly and there is the roar of a tremendous crowd the white, green with white crescent, flag of Pakistan is raised on the flagpole.

dialogues.speaker: THE ASHRAM
dialogues.text: Silence. The little flagpole is empty, the rope dangling, flapping loosely down the pole. Gandhi sits on the porch of his bungalow, spinning. The h of the spinning wheel. Inside we can just see Mirabehn,  spinning too. But apart from that, he is alone; the whole ashram seems deserted. We hear the sound of a bell on one the goats, fairly distant.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATH TO THE ASHRAM
dialogues.text: Featuring Kallenbach. He is taking the goat and tethering near the path of the ashram. He stills the bell with his  hand. As he ties it the camera angle widens and we see  Margaret Bourke-White sitting on the grass, watching  Kallenbach and looking off toward Gandhi's bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you being a little  overprotective?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kallenbach looks at her. Her tone criticizes more than hi stilling the goat's bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Tomorrow photograph him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came all this way because I believed  the picture of Independence Day was  of him here alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kallenbach stands and looks across at her, judging, then  appealing to her humanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is violence, and the fear of  violence, that have made today what  it is... Give him the dignity of his  grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourke-White grabs a clump of grass, twists it free, and  sighs. She tosses the grass vaguely at the goat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And while we're sitting here feeding  goats, what will happen to all the  Muslims in India and the Hindus in  Pakistan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kallenbach stops, staring absently at the ground ahead, t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi will pray for them...

dialogues.speaker: OPEN TERRAIN AND RAILROAD
dialogues.text: The camera is high (helicopter) and moving and from its  position we meet and then pass over an immense column of  refugees -- ten, twenty abreast -- moving down one side o the railroad track toward camera. Women, children, the si the aged, all burdened with bedding, utensils, household  treasures, useless bric-a-brac and trudging with them eve type of cart, wagon, rickshaw, pulled by donkey, camel, b oxen. It stretches endlessly to the horizon. Tiny green,  white and saffron flags here and there indicate that it i Hindu column and spotted through it we see people in fres bandages, some on stretchers, sticking out like radioacti tracers in the huge artery of frightened humanity. And the camera lifts and tilts, slowly swinging to the  opposite direction, and as it does, reveals another vast  column across the track, several yards away, moving in th opposite direction: veiled women in purdah, the crescent  flag of Muslim Pakistan here and there. As the camera lev and speeds along it, we see that this column too reaches the horizon, that it too carries its wounded. An unbelievable flood of desperate humanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of the vast refugee column. A woman's arms crad a baby in swaddling. Blood has seeped through the swaddli in three or four places, some of it dried. Flies buzz aro it. And suddenly we hear the woman's sobs and she rocks t baby and we know it has stopped moving, stopped breathing and a male hand gently touches the back of the baby, chec and the camera pans up to the face of a man. Again in extreme close shot so we cannot tell whether the are Hindu or Muslim. And the man's eyes knot, and he swin out of shot as he runs in fury and rage at the other colu

dialogues.speaker: HIGH
dialogues.text: The two columns -- and a howl of hate and grief! And the  camera sweeps to where men are running at each other acro the track, some already fighting. Knives, pangas, hatchet women screaming and running; a besieged wagon tipped. Another angle. And as the fighting grows more fierce stre of men from each column run back to partake, but the bulk the two columns hurries off, scrambling, running, some le their bundles, fleeing the meleГ© in terror.

dialogues.speaker: HINDU/MUSLIM RIOT SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: A Muslim pulled through broken glass in an urban market s Night: a Hindu temple daubed with blood, the bodies of wo and children strewn before it; screams, the sound of  fighting./ Mud and straw houses burning, figures running  through them./ A city street: a truck crashes into a barr of rickshaws and bales, and is set upon by a swarm of kni and panga-bearing men. From the back of the truck opponen with swords and clubs leap into battle.

dialogues.speaker: NEHRU'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Chaos. It and the adjoining office have been made into  something like operations rooms. Military and civilian ai move back and forth. Telephones at work everywhere. A hug map on the wall is constantly having data changed by peop receiving messages there. Nehru is glancing at a telex message; he turns and gives back to the military aide who's given it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fast, curt) No. There just are not that many  troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What he can!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns. Patel has a message he was going to present to  him. He hesitates, grins dismally, and crumples the messa "No use." Nehru sags. He looks at Patel with haggard eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was right. It's insane -- anything  would have been better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you found him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru nods solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in Noakhali.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patel reacts to that -- surprise, apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's tramping from village to village --  no police, no troops -- trying to  quell the madness single-handedly. (He sighs, half in  admiration, half in  hopeless exasperation  at the old man's  audacity.) Maulana has gone to bring him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patel nods grimly -- the noisy chaos of the room. Someone shouts at Nehru, "Prime Minister!"

dialogues.speaker: GANDHI
dialogues.text: In silence -- looking tragic, tired and defeated. He is  sitting in his characteristic manner, staring down at the carpet before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dull, lifeless) What you have done in Noakhali is a  miracle, Bapu, a miracle, but millions  are on the move -- millions. There  is no way to stop it... and no one  can count the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera angle has changed. We are in

dialogues.speaker: NEHRU'S PRIVATE CHAMBERS
dialogues.text: Patel and Azad are there and Pyarelal of course, and with them now the giant figure of Abdul Ghaffar Khan, the firs time we have seen him among Gandhi's intimate group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Calcutta it's like civil war. The  Muslims rose and there was a  bloodbath, and now the Hindus are  taking revenge -- and if we can't  stop it there'll be no hope for the  Hindus left in Pakistan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...an eye for an eye making the whole  world blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is an empty and despairing echo of Gandhi's words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't there any troops to spare?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tense, fragile) Nothing -- nothing. The divisions in  Bombay and Delhi can hardly keep the  peace now. And each fresh bit of  news creates another wave of  mad...  ness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has turned and seen Gandhi standing slowly. It has alm stopped him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we cut all news off? I know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu -- please. Where are you going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sounding like an old  man) I don't want to hear more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is moving toward the door. It stops them all. Pyarelal moves tentatively to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) We need your help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nothing I can give.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi turns, looks at him bleakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calcutta.

dialogues.speaker: CALCUTTA
dialogues.text: We are high. There are fires, the sounds of spasmodic gun of looting, screams, the roar of police vehicles and  occasional sirens. The camera zooms in on a poor quarter artisan dwellings in narrow streets. Outside one of the h is a car, an army jeep, policemen, a few soldiers and a g of people. It seems a little island of calm in a sea of w chaos. On the roof of the house, a figure moves into the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure is Gandhi. He peers down at the dark, rioting  streets. Azad, Tahib, a Muslim whose house this is, Mirab and Pyarelal are with him along Abdul Ghaffar Khan. A police commissioner moves to Gandhi's side, demanding h attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, please, I don't have the men to  protect you -- not in a Muslim house.  Not this quarter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am staying with the friend of a  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sudden commotion just below them and angry sho "Death to Muslims!," "Death to Muslims!" Gandhi peers down. His point of view. A surging gang of youths, many carryin torches, and far outnumbering the little group of police soldiers, are shouting up at the roof. We see three or fo black flags and stains of blood on many of them. A few ho knives still wet with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A feral roar goes up at the sight of Gandhi, but he stand unmoving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice emotional,  tearful) Why are you staying at the home of a  Muslim! They're murderers! They killed  my family!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring Gandhi. It is a comment too grave for glibness, and Gandhi is obviously struck by the pain of it. He paus for a moment, staring down at the youth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because forgiveness is the gift of  the brave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes it mean the youth. For a second it makes an impa but then the youth shouts his defiance at him and his mes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hell with you, Gandhi!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An angry chorus of acclamation; when it dies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the youth) Go -- do as your mother and father  would wish you to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is ambiguous, open-ended, meaning anything your mother and father would wish you to do. Tears flush from the boy eyes and he stares at Gandhi with a kind of hopeless angu and rage. But the impact is on the youth alone; around hi the others begin to take up the chant "Death to Muslims!, "Death to Muslims!" Gandhi turns from the street. He looks at the police  commissioner -- at his fatigue, his concern, his manifest respect. Gandhi musters a weary smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have lived a lifetime. If I had  shunned death -- or feared it -- I  would not be here. Nor would you be  concerned for me. (He lets it sink in  then he takes the  commissioner's arm  and moves back toward  the center of the  roof.) Leave me -- and take your men. (An understanding  touch of the arm.) You have more important things to  worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The commissioner looks at him, uncertain, not knowing wha to do, as the angry chanting continues above the sound of rioting.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: An old, inadequate hospital -- dark cavernous. Margaret B White is moving among the densely packed litter of wounde women. She is positioning herself to photograph Gandhi, w is speaking to a woman who cradles a small baby. The corr behind him are even more packed. The few doctors and nurs hardly have room to move. Featuring Gandhi. Azad and Mirabehn are behind him as he  moves on, and behind them, like a giant guardian, Abdul  Ghaffar Khan. We hear "Bapu, Bapu" muttered quietly here there. Gandhi bends to a woman whose face is bandaged and cruel wound is half-exposed between her mouth and eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu... Allah be with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are tears in Gandhi's eyes now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with you. (He touches her  wrinkled hand.) Pray... I cannot help you -- pray...  pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the weight of his helplessness hangs on him.

dialogues.speaker: CALCUTTA STREET
dialogues.text: A streetcar (tram) crashes into a barricade of carts,  rickshaws, a couple of old cars, smashing through to brea the barricade, but stopped in the end by the mass of debr The streetcar is loaded with Indian troops and they break from the stalled vehicle to chase A gang of Hindus --  organized -- runs down the street from the troops, some  dragging the bodies of victims with them. We see several  Hindu black flags.

dialogues.speaker: NEHRU'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: He speaks across his desk to a senior police commissioner The same activity going on in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) No! There will not be a Hindu Police  and a Muslim Police. There is one  police!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aide slips a newspaper on his desk in front of him. He doesn't look at it till the senior commissioner lowers hi head and turns, accepting defeat. Then Nehru glances at t paper. In thick headlines: GANDHI: A FAST UNTO DEATH! Nehru doesn't move for a moment. Then he lifts his face s to his aide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why must I read news like this in  the paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aide shakes his head -- there's no answer. Nehru lowe his head again; it is like another burden on a man who al has too many. He grips his temples... a terrible sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Patel. Arrange a plane. We will  go -- Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru thinks on it solemnly, then nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: TAHIB'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The sounds of rioting and looting on nearby streets, but  here a mass of people are gathered. Many youths with blac flags. Two black government limousines. Motorcycles. Poli and soldiers. They are looking off to

dialogues.speaker: AN OUTSIDE STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: It runs up the side of the building and is lined with wai people. Nehru and Patel are climbing the stairs, moving p them almost irritably as they mutter "Nehru, Nehru," "Pat and make the pranam to the eminent men. In the heat of the city Tahib's rooftop is still Gandhi's "home" and has become a center of activity. Azad clears  someone aside and ushers Nehru and Patel under the canopy awning. Nehru pauses as he lowers his head. His point of view. Gandhi lies curled awkwardly on his si of the cot. He is writing, Pyarelal taking the pages as h finishes, both ignoring all the people, the sounds of gun and distant shouting, but he looks tired and tightens his jaw occasionally in pain. The camera pans. A doctor sits  near the foot of the cot, Abdul Ghaffar Khan beyond him.  Near the other edge of the canopied area, Mirabehn sits w Bourke-White. They are whispering quietly, but Mirabehn h stopped on seeing Nehru and she smiles a relieved greetin She knows Gandhi's feeling for him. Bourke-White stares a him and Patel for a second and then her hand goes slowly, almost reflexively, for her camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru crosses and kneels so that he is almost at Gandhi's eyeline. Gandhi must take his eyes from his writing to lo and he is almost moved to tears at the sight of Nehru. Hi hand shakes a little as he holds it out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi turns to pat their joined hands with his other han He does so with effort, and at last he sees Patel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sardar... (He looks him over.) You have gained weight. You must  join me in the fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patel sits near the head of the cot so the three of them on a level. Outside the canopied area, Bourke-White is  crouched, her camera framing the three of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wittily, warmly) If I fast I die. If you fast people  go to all sorts of trouble to keep  you alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi smiles and reaches to touch hands with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu, forgive me -- I've cheated. I  could have come earlier. But your  fast has helped. These last days  people's minds have begun to turn to  this bed -- and away from last night's  atrocity. But now it is enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that has happened is that I've  grown a little thinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is despairingly sincere. But Nehru feels he has an ant for that despair. The distant sound of an explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow five thousand Muslim students  of all ages are marching here in  Calcutta -- for peace. (The real point) And five thousand Hindu students are  marching with them. It is all  organized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourke-White captures the sense of elation in his face. F her discreet distance, she lowers the camera, holding it  against her mouth, waiting for Gandhi's response. Gandhi nods to Nehru, accepting the news with a sad  wistfulness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad -- but it will not be enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru isn't prepared for this resistance. He glances at P and we see that they recognize that their bland convictio that they could talk him out of the fast was deeply mispl Nehru turns back -- this time no confidence, only concern forced smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu, you are not so young anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi smiles, pain etched in his eyes. He touches Nehru' hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry for me -- death will be  a deliverance. (There is water in  his eyes, but his  words have the weight  of a man truly  determined to die.) I cannot watch the destruction of  all I have lived for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru stares at him, feeling the sudden fear that Gandhi  means it. Patel, Mirabehn, Azad, Bourke-White are gripped the same realization.

dialogues.speaker: TAHIB'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: An outside broadcast truck is parked among the usual crow grown even larger now, and more women among them. The sou of distant fighting.

dialogues.speaker: TAHIB'S ROOF
dialogues.text: The senior technician, in earphones, signals across to  Mirabehn. She holds a microphone by Gandhi, who is lying his side. He seems almost out of touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi looks at her, and then the microphone. When he spe into the microphone his voice is very weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each night before I sleep, I read a  few words from the Gita and the Koran,  and the Bible... (we intercut with  Bourke-White and  those on the roof  watching) tonight I ask you to share these  thoughts of God with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now we go into the streets, intercutting with Gandhi seeing Hindus listening around loudspeakers on corners, i little eating houses, Muslim shops where people live in t back, and neighbors gathering defensively in groups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the books are there,  but he does it from  memory of course) I will begin with the Bible where  the words of the Lord are, "Love thy  neighbor as thyself"... and then our  beloved Gita which says, "The world  is a garment worn by God, thy neighbor  is in truth thyself"... and finally  the Holy Koran, "We shall remove all  hatred from our hearts and recline  on couches face to face, a band of  brothers."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans back, exhausted. Mirabehn is looking at him; she starts to sing softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Lead Kindly Light, amidst the  circling gloom..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi, his eyes closed, takes it up in his weak, croakin voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The night is dark, and I am far  from home, Lead thou me on..."

dialogues.speaker: TAHIB'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Two police motorcycles lead a black limousine to a stop b Tahib's house. The crowd now gathered is very large. More mixed than before but still predominantly of youths, many still with black flags. Nehru gets out of the limousine with a Muslim leader, a t looking man who carries himself with the authority and po of a mobster (Suhrawardy). And they start to go up the ou stairs. Suddenly we hear the shout "Death to Gandhi!," "Death to  Gandhi!" And Nehru turns, pushing past Suhrawardy fiercel and going back onto the street. He runs at the crowd, whe the shout comes once more from the back. His face is wild with anger and shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterically) Who dares say such things! Who?! (And he is running at  them and they spread  in fear.) Come! Kill me first! Come! Where are  you?! Kill me first!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd has spread from him all along the street; they  stand against the walls of the houses staring at him,  terrified to move. We see, just in passing, the frightene apprehensive faces of Godse, and near him, Apte and Karka Nehru stands, staring at them all, his face seething with anger.

dialogues.speaker: TAHIB'S ROOF
dialogues.text: We are featuring a copy of Life Magazine. On the cover is picture of rioting men fighting and diagonally a cut-out Gandhi lying on his cot. The caption reads: "An Old Man's Battle." As the magazine starts to be opened, it is sudde put to one side. Another angle. Mirabehn is rising, leaving the magazine a her feet. She moves to Nehru and Suhrawardy as Azad usher them into the canopied area. Abdul Ghaffar Khan sits quie in the background. Mirabehn speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His pulse is very irregular -- the  kidneys aren't functioning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru looks across at Gandhi. The doctor, who is testing  Gandhi's pulse yet again, glances at him -- no encouragem and moves away. Nehru moves to the side of the cot and Ga smiles weakly and holds out a hand, but he is in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu, I have brought Mr. Suhrawardy.  It was he who called on the Muslims  to rise; he is telling them now to  go back to their homes, to lay down  their arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi looks up at Suhrawardy, who nods. Gandhi looks bac at Nehru. There is no hint of him changing his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (personally) Think what you can do by living --  that you cannot do by dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi smiles whimsically, he touches him again but there no change in his attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleadingly) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a moment) That the fighting will stop -- that  you make me believe it will never  start again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nehru looks at him hopelessly.

dialogues.speaker: SQUARE IN CALCUTTA
dialogues.text: A huge crowd, some smoke in distant buildings, some damag near to help us know this is still Calcutta, and all is n yet at peace. The camera sweeps over the crowd, past the  loudspeakers on their poles. We see surly knots of bellig rowdies, mostly young, but not all, hanging on the fringe as we move over the heads of the mass of listening people a platform where Nehru speaks. Azad, Suhrawardy, and othe sit on the floor behind him. We have heard his voice over all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sometimes it is when you are quite  without hope and in utter darkness  that God comes to the rescue. Gandhiji  is dying because of our madness. Put  away your "revenge." What will be  gained by more killing? Have the  courage to do what you know is right.  For God's sake, let us embrace like  brothers...

dialogues.speaker: TAHIB'S ROOF
dialogues.text: Featuring the Muslim leader Suhrawardy, leaning against a wall, watching an action out of shot with evident tension We hear a little clank of metal. Another angle. There are five men facing Gandhi. They wea black trousers and black knit vests. There are thongs aro their arms that make their bulging muscles seem even more powerful. They are Hindu thugs (Goondas). Their clothes a dirty -- and they are too -- but they are laying knives a guns at Gandhi's feet. Mirabehn, Azad, Pyarelal, the doctor and others on the ro watch fascinated, a little frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is our promise. We stop. It is a  promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi is looking at him, testing, not giving or acceptin anything that is mere gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go -- try -- God by with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Goondas stand. They glance at Suhrawardy; he smiles t and they start to leave, but one (Nahari) lingers. Sudden he moves violently toward Gandhi, taking a flat piece of  Indian bread (chapati) from his trousers and tossing it  forcefully on Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn and Azad start to move toward him -- the man loo immensely strong and immensely unstable. But Gandhi holds a shaking hand, stopping them. Nahari's face is knotted i emotion, half anger, half almost a child's fear -- but th is a wild menace in  that instability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat! I am going to hell -- but not  with your death on my soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only God decides who goes to hell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffening, aggressive) I -- I killed a child... (Then an anguished  defiance) I smashed his head against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi stares at him, breathless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a fearful whisper) Why? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is as though the man has told him of some terrible sel inflicted wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tears now -- and  wrath) They killed my son -- my boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost reflexively he holds his hand out to indicate the  height of his son. He glares at Suhrawardy and then back Gandhi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Muslims killed my son... they  killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sobbing, but in his anger it seems almost as though means to kill Gandhi in retaliation. A long moment, as Ga meets his pain and wrath. Then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a way out of hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nahari sneers, but there is just a flicker of desperate  curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find a child -- a child whose mother  and father have been killed. A little  boy -- about this high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises his hand to the height Nahari has indicated as son's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and raise him -- as your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nahari has listened. His face almost cracks -- it is a ch of light, but it does not illumine his darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only be sure... that he is a Muslim.  And that you raise him as one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now the light falls on Nahari. His face stiffens, he  swallows, fighting any show of emotion; then he turns to But he takes only a step and he turns back, going to his  knees, the sobs breaking again and again from his heaving body as he holds his head to Gandhi's feet in the traditi greeting of Hindu son to Hindu father. A second, and Gand reaches out and touches the top of his head. Mirabehn watches. The Goondas watch. Suhrawardy watches.  Finally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently, exhaustedly) Go -- go. God bless you...

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Trucks with riot squads (shields and truncheons) in place but they are lounging, waiting. There is silence, and air somnolence. Some of the riot squad lounge in little group around the courtyard. A distant cough. Featuring a senior riot squad officer dressed and ready f action. He it is who coughed. He coughs again, clearing h throat. A police sergeant stands by him, both are reading the front page of a paper the senior riot squad officer h We see two huge lines of headline: GANDHI NEAR DEATH/NEHR GOES ON FAST. In one of the trucks one of the men offers another a  cigarette. A telephone rings sharply, inside. The senior riot squad  officer and the sergeant run in as engines start; the men run to their places, lower visors, headlights go on!

dialogues.speaker: POLICE STATION OFFICE
dialogues.text: A constable mans the telephone. He listens as the senior  riot squad officer and the sergeant run to him tensely. T sound of the great doors opening in the courtyard, more  engines revving up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, yes, sir, (He holds up his hand  to the senior officer) "Wait."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances up at the senior riot squad officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing, from the  phone) Accident, "Christie crossroads," a  lorry and a rickshaw. Yes, sir, I  have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs at the senior riot squad officer and hands the  information slip to another constable behind the desk. The sergeant sighs, and moves to the outside door. We hea him bellow, "Stand down." The constable hangs up and sigh heavily. The senior riot squad officer shakes his head, a turns and walks slowly to the door.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: The senior riot squad officer and the sergeant stand in t doorway as the engines die. The men relax... the silence  returns. A dog barks distantly, disturbed by the noise... bird caws once or twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have believed it, Mr.  Gupta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, it's a bloody miracle...

dialogues.speaker: CALCUTTA
dialogues.text: It lies in silence.

dialogues.speaker: TAHIB'S ROOF
dialogues.text: Mirabehn is bent over Gandhi. He is curled almost in the  fetal position, his face looking wan and sunken. For the  first time there is silence, no explosions, no distant sh no gunfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu, there's been no fighting --  anywhere. It has stopped -- the  madness has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the police commissioner, Suhrawardy, two doctors,  Abdul Ghaffar Khan, and some others. Nearer Gandhi, behin Mirabehn, are Nehru, Patel, Azad and Pyarelal. Gandhi turns to Mirabehn, his face shaking, peering into eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is foolish if it is just to save  the life of an old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no. In every temple and mosque  they have pledged to die before they  lift a hand against each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His weary eyes look at her; he looks up slowly to Azad. A nods "It's true." Then Patel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi looks at Nehru. Nehru just nods tautly. Gandhi loo down, then lifts his head to Azad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maulana, my friend, could I have  some orange juice... Then you and I  will take a piece of bread together...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The relief brings water to their eyes and grins to their  faces. Nehru bends to Gandhi. Gandhi holds his hand out t him, and Nehru clutches it. Then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Bapu, it is not difficult.  I have fasted only a few hours and I  accomplished what you could not do  in as many days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a joke in their way with each other and Gandhi's ey light, his smile comes. But it is tired. He puts his othe hand over Nehru's and Nehru lowers his head to it, crying silently.

dialogues.speaker: BIRLA HOUSE
dialogues.text: As in the opening sequence -- but a few minutes earlier. crowd is beginning to gather for the evening prayers. We a tonga or two, a gardener opening the gate to the garden three policemen standing, talking idly among themselves.

dialogues.speaker: BIRLA HOUSE
dialogues.text: Laughter. Gandhi is eating muli; he holds his head back t capture the lemon juice. We hear the click of a camera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is how you eat muli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manu hands him a cloth and he wipes his hands. Another cl of a camera. He is not fully recovered, but well on the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the photographer) I'm not sure I want to be remembered  that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is all light and for fun. We get a wide-angle shot now and see that Bourke-White is shooting one of her favorite subjects again. She is enjoying the banter, as is Mirabeh who is spinning quietly to one side of the room, and Pate who sits cross-legged like Gandhi on the floor. Pyarelal working on papers with him but grins at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, with luck you may not  be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she shoots him again, as he hands the cloth back to M Abha is sitting next to Manu, looking at a collection of  pictures of Gandhi, obviously Bourke-White's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he'll be remembered for tempting  fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is wry, but waspishly chiding. Abha suddenly holds a  picture up for Gandhi to see. It's one of him, ears wide, eyes round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey Mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi taps her on the head with his finger as she smiles But Bourke-White has looked from Patel to Gandhi, clearly shaken by the implication in Patel's words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really are going to Pakistan,  then? (Gandhi shrugs, and  she chides too) You are a stubborn man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a grin, in the mood  of their "flirtation") I'm simply going to prove to Muslims  there, and Hindus here, that the  only devils in the world are those  running around in our own hearts --  and that's where all our battles  ought to be fought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abha has signaled to the cheap watch dangling from his dh He glances at it, and holds his arms out. The two girls h him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what kind of a warrior have you  been in that warfare?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is photographing his getting-up and leaning on the tw girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a very good one. That's why I  have so much tolerance for the other  scoundrels of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves off, but has a sudden thought and turns to Patel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask Panditji to -- to consider what  we've discussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patel nods soberly and Gandhi starts for the door, Bourke White moving with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of the photographs) Enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a plea) One more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has passed her, he's in the doorway. We see the crowd the end of the garden, where the light of the day is begi to soften. He turns, teasing in his slightly flirtatious with women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a temptress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoots him against the door -- the crowd milling  distantly, waiting -- then she lowers her camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just an admirer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's more dangerous, especially  for an old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns; the last words have betrayed the smile on his f they have a painful sense of truth about them. Bourke-Whi watches as he moves into the garden toward the crowd in t distance. She turns to Mirabehn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a sadness in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an observation -- and a question. Mirabehn accedes  gravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks he's failed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourke-White stares at her, then turns to look out at him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? My God, if anything's proved  him right, it's what's happened these  last months...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabehn nods, but she keeps on spinning and tries to sou cynically resigned but her innate emotionalism keeps brea through in her voice and on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am blinded by my love of him, but  I think when we most needed it, he  offered the world a way out of  madness. But he doesn't see it...  and neither does the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is laced with pain. Bourke-White turns and looks out a Gandhi -- so tiny, so weak as he walks between his "props He has now reached the end of the garden and is moving am the crowd assembled there.

dialogues.speaker: THE GARDEN
dialogues.text: Gandhi is moving forward in the crowd, one hand resting o Manu, the other on Abha. He makes the pranam to someone, crowd is bowing to him, some speaking, and we also see th crowd from his point of view -- "Bapu," "God bless you,"  "Thank you -- thank you." He turns to a very old woman, w makes a salaam to him. Gandhi touches her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allah be with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiling, he turns back. A jostling, the sound of beads  falling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to someone) Brother, Bapu is already late for  prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandhi turns to the person; he makes the pranam. Full shot. Godse is making the pranam to him and he sudde wildly draws his gun and fires. The camera closes on Gand as he staggers and falls, the red stain of blood seeping  through his white shawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God... oh, God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manu and Abha bend over him, silent in their first shock. The sound of panic and alarm begins to grow around them,  they suddenly scream and begin to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bapu! Bapu!

dialogues.speaker: FUNERAL PYRE
dialogues.text: Blackness. Silence. A moment -- we sense the blackness moving -- like dark sm The camera is pulling back very slowly and we can tell th blackness is smoke rising from a fire. And now we see that it is a funeral pyre. And all around  that pyre a mass of silent humanity. Through the smoke,  sitting cross-legged near the rim of the flames, we see  Nehru... and Azad and Patel, Mirabehn and Kallenbach, the drawn faces of Lord and Lady Mountbatten, Manu and Abha..

dialogues.speaker: THE RIVER
dialogues.text: A helicopter shot coming slowly up the wide river, low, t a barge and a mass of people in the distance. And now we are over the barge, and it is covered with flo Flowers flow downstream around it. An urn sits on it --  containing Gandhi's ashes -- and Nehru stands near it, Az and Patel a little behind him. And as the barge floats do the river, Nehru bends and lifts the urn... Featuring Nehru. He swallows, restraining his own emotion and slowly, ritualistically, sprinkles the ashes over the water. And as they spread, we hold on that stretch of the river, the flowers swirling languidly around it as the dark, tim current moves them toward the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weak, struggling, as  he spoke the words  to Mirabehn) ...There have been tyrants and  murderers -- and for a time they can  seem invincible. But in the end they  always fall. Think of it -- always...  When you are in doubt that that is  God's way, the way the world is meant  to be... think of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And slowly the camera begins pulling back, leaving the  flowers, the brown, rolling current as though leaving the story of Gandhi, going far out, away from the great river reaching higher and higher, through streaks of clouds as titles begin. And through them, once more we hear, dimly, reminiscently through the rushing wind: "At home children are writing 'essays' about him!"... the croaky voice singing, "God save our gracious King"... Dye "Sergeant Major --," the Sergeant Major: "Take aim!," Dye "Fire!," the sound of massed rifle fire, screams... "You my best friend... my highest guru, and my sovereign lord. "Who the hell is he?," "I don't know, sir." "My name is  Gandhi. Mohandas K. Gandhi."... the sound of rioting, wom screams, terror... "Find a child -- a child whose mother father have been killed. A little boy... about this high. "He thinks he's failed."... "Long live Mahatma Gandhi!... Long live Mahatma Gandhi!"
